posts.com:
sovlful edition

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

posts.com:
Beefheart Anon here.
I'm trying to think of a way to draw a certain being. I think I should sort of recreate it with a Beksinski/Giger-esque artstyle. It's sort of like if Lovecraft thought of a monstrous freight train straight from hell.

I think in the past centuries of America, maybe even in the era of the mythical Wild West, it could appear at the train station, at the platform, opening the doors to its innards , giving the passengers a chance to enter.
A kind of beast that has adapted to the creations and actions of man, choosing to move through now popular railroad tracks of a then younger America, merging together with the now binded clueless passengers, never to be found again.

"A chain with yellow lights
That glistens like oil beads
On its slick smooth trunk
That trails behind on tracks, and thumps
A wing hangs limp and retrieves

Bulbs shoot from its snoot
And vanish into darkness
It whistles like a root snatched from dry earth
Sodbustin’ rakes with grey dust claws
Announces its coming into morning
This train with grey tubes
That houses people’s very thoughts and belongings.

Bat chain puller
Puller, puller

This train with grey tubes that houses people’s thoughts,
Their very remains and belongings.
A grey cloth patch
Caught with four threads
In the hollow wind of its stacks
Ripples felt fades and grey sparks clacks,
Lunge into cushioned thickets.
Pumpkins span the hills
With orange crayola patches.
Green inflated trees
Balloon up into marshmallow soot
That walks away in faulty circles,
Caught in grey blisters
With twinkling lights and green sashes
Drawn by rubber dolphins with gold yawning mouths
That blister and break in agony
In zones of rust
They guild gold sawdust into dust."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474733
Sketches look better because:
1) you chicken scratch/draw multiple lines and your brain imagines a better drawing than what you've actually drawn
2) you draw big confident strokes when you sketch but small slow-moving cautious strokes when you ink
With digital ink lines I try to adjust the stabiliser.
When it comes to painting keep in mind you're not just working with line anymore, you can't just suggest the form and shape, you have to be more specific, so if the form and shape and lighting isn't exciting colour can kinda ruin the picture.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6475802
if you practice copying references, you get better at copying references
unless your references are simple geometric shapes, you're not going to improve at drawing simple geometric shapes, the word "simple" here is misleading, nothing is simple, you have to learn how to draw a thing before you can turn a different thing into said thing
you know what a cone or prism looks like in the same way you know what a leg or a face looks like, that is to say: you don't really, your brain just tells you that you do and then leaves you on read when you ask for proof
it's why i keep saying that construction is bad for real beginners with the way people here market it as a solution to incompetence rather than a technique like any other

>>6475824
It's just something I've gradually become accustomed to over years of drawing. Started out just drawing things that interested me, and because it looked like crap I looked up any references that could tell me about what I struggled with, and over time just accumulated a feel for it. I'm still a far way away from where I'd like to be, but I've only started drawing daily very recently. Previously it was only a few days a month or so. I'd reccommend something like what you see in the bottom page on my photo where I iterate the same image a few times, focusing in on a certain portion and in an attempt to get it right, then once you've done that you might try to go a step further and draw the same thing from a different angle, but that's pretty advanced.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474800
Over time I got used to my tablet, and I settled into a sweet spot where I don't adjust as much it anymore. But basically, if you're drawing a big, slow line, turn up stabilisation so that your jittery hands don't affect the smoothness of the line. Turn down stabilisation for light, quick strokes.
It's really a matter of confidence in the end, doing a lot of ink drawings (trad) with no undo can help you get over the "I did it wrong, undo" feeling

ok, go copy some golden era early 2000s CN genndy tartakovsky/craig mccracken characters or anything similiar to that in complexity and do it such that you get them almost perfectly right, good enough to be absolutely, unmistakably on-model proportionally; don't shit it all out on the paper in a matter of seconds and then scribble over it, take the time it needs to be correct, copy the lines, carefully, patiently analyze their sizes, angles and trajectories, no construction; once you get a couple of them right and realize how hard even that is, you'll understand why copying photos of real people at your skill level is a fool's errand
stop doing the loomis method and other techniques that you clearly can't even follow or even draw correctly in and of themselves, you should already be aware of a voice in the back of your head telling you that you can't do it, you can't use it and that it isn't helping you, but i'll go ahead reaffirm that for you: you can't do it, you can't use it, and until you change that, it will only hinder you; it's basically a pre-sketch religious ritual at this point
then go do draw a box to improve your lines and geometry, completely forget all the bullshit about any theory you think you've understood, you haven't understood any of it and that's not entirely your fault, the sticky is full of shit advice that shitters regurgitate in order to fit in

ear too smoll,

head too large but can be chalked up to a cartoony look,

HIS neck is a combination of trapezoids and the neck , try seperating the two visually somehow ,
abdominal curve looks ok ish

right fist looks blocky but has depth

, left one looks terrible

right forearm needs some work / looks too short

there is no elbow skin fold which is seen when the arm is bent

Neck is too right leaning (prolly a resoult of combining traps and neck

groin needs some work (look at obliqe muscles and where the leg muscles "crawl "underneath them (obliqes are sometimes called a dickroot because there is a tendon that points to your dick and is vissible in muscular buit low fat people .

Your feet game will be on point as soon as the toes get better - proko might have a utube vid on it,

beg for sure but a spirited one, dont get comfy with your stile , you will make strides in the beggining , especially if you follow a guide or have a teacher

Why You Should Copy Anime:

Krenz Accuracy Imgs :https://files.catbox.moe/tklkj8.rar

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6465776
assistants tools usually take cpu cycles to keep calculating stuff even on idle, this may cause lag on bigger projects, also the farther the vanishing points the more resource it may use...

Using a image template (raster level) there is no thinking involve, so less prone in lagging another benefit is that as the template is just another layer I can apply all the functions available to layers (blending modes, stacking order, masking, etc.) I can't imagine making something like a comic strip in which every panel may have a different vanishing points from each other with assistants tools.
Ended up using this templates, https://www.davidrevoy.com/article814/perspective-grids-for-comics-in-krita
but I think I will make an 8k version.

Did I make myself understood?, I'm mentally drained kek

Done, yes, it is chalk from csp. From a quick test on krita it can be replicated using "chalk details" brush and playing around with pattern strength. For some reason this brush is much easier to give a seamless continuation using multiple overlapping strokes while having a nice line weight, probably because of the coarseness of the pattern.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6465902
I think you should trace real people and anime characters, and get a feel for the curves, anatomy and how they are normally shaped.
You have some idea on what to do, but you may over exxagerate some stuff to a point thing it may look wrong, tracing should help bring it back to normal levels.
The word tracing may sound icky, but it helped for me and made me see what i got wrong despite figure drawing and study constantly, tracing just made it click.

If it helps, make some notes; i made the hp bone too sharp, my toes have too much definition, my shoulders are not as slender. Do stuff like that and you'll get afeel for how it's meant to be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6469437
you are drawing symbols. in other words, you are putting flat stickers of eyes and mouth on a template when you're supposed to draw things with volume and perspective in mind
for example, in a front shot, the eyes and mouth don't curve upward like that, they curve toward the face because they protrude off of it. you drew it as if you were looking from above although still wrong
my personal advice whould be to look into the planes of the face and features so you know how to apply perspective to them. believe it or not, although the average anime face looks fairly simple it still relies on understanding the structure of a real face to make it look cute

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474370
Keep the skin tone simple first, just work with 4.
1. Select the base flesh tone and fill body.
2. Select a lighter tone for highlights over softly.
3. Select a deeper tone for shadow areas, again softly apply.
4 Select a midway tone between the shadow and base tone to blend all.

>>6474625

You could make her face longer if you wanted, but you'd need to pay attention to where you're placing the cheekbones (aka where the line bends). On your original the cheeks were placed very low, which made the face look like a sheet of paper.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6475952
Find some proportion diagrams, look at them, copy them, roughly sketch the diagrams from memory, check them. Keep it in mind when you start drawing figures from life or reference, and when you draw poses from imagination.
All that said, you can always use reference. Keep studying anatomy, perspective, proportion, etc as you draw, but don't think you need to be a master of everything before you finally start drawing what you want to draw; don't think you need to reach the magical point of "everything I draw is entirely from my mind" before you start producing the art you want to produce. Never be afraid to use references, especially with all the libraries of reference photos out there, pose dolls/software, your own body and camera, etc etc., but you'll find that the more you draw, the less you'll have to rely on references as starting points and the more you'll use them as helpers or checks.

posts.com:
Why is the top down learning approach significantly more often taught than the bottom up one?

I think there is something deeply wrong with how beginners are taught. As a child, I drew from children books and worked my way up to cartoons, comics and then photography. This seems to be the natural progression of art, we start with cave drawings and as we notice the complexities of reality we work our way up to oil paintings. Why is it then, that beginners are so often taught to draw from real life? In my humble opinion, this is completely overwhelming to a starter.

Think of it this way - virtually every other skill taught out there goes from simple to complex.

In a highly stialized drawing the value of a line and colour is greater, as beginners learn to draw they can learn to reapect each descission they make. Working their way up as natural progression goes.

That approach only makes sense if learning as you grow up, a toddler cannot grasp complex life or mechanical drawings, but as their cognition develops, so can their ability to draw more and more accurately.
The problem with teaching like that, is every step of the journey involves unlearning bad habits and shortcuts and replacing them with better ones, that's why drawing is often taught going straight to the point. Yes, it can be tougher since real life is complex, that's why usually what is first taught is how to observe and simplify forms, but teaching begshit you will have to unteach as you go is dumb as shit.

They key word here is FROM. Realism is only hard if you're trying to conjure up imagery purely from your mind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474581
This is kind of an open question but it seems most places start teaching with copies from the flat + life drawing. You're right that you need the training wheels first, but you also need to develop the ability to observe from life quickly because it will teach you how the 2d works you copy are "styled." You are consciously or unconsciously building a shape library in your head, so if you just copy 10,000 bad drawings, you're damaging your aesthetic progress. If you are a beg, this is made much worse by the fact that you don't really know what a good drawing is yet. Drawing from life doesn't have this last problem, and will always help you see, depict, and appreciate beauty directly, no matter your skill level.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474581
A lot of it depends on goals. Do you want to improve quickly and suffer, or improve slowly and have fun?
The thing with art education and training is that they are there to improve your skills as efficiently as possible, and what is fun is ultimately up to the student. The instructor would be wasting their students' time by forcing them to do things that won't show as much improvement and may not even be fun to the individual. Things like fun and creativity might not be directly important to improvement, but they can prevent you from getting burnt out and being the type of anon who does nothing but grind, then complains on this board about how art makes him want to kill himself.
If you really want to have fun, it would be better to go find a community somewhere else on the internet with other people who don't take things so seriously, then come back here every once in a while if you actually need something critiqued.

>>6470632

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6470632
refine the chin placement it follows a rigid pathing make it follow some sort of smooth arch it'll look more natural that way
the bangs have a nice delayed action to them good job : D
also i'd suggest drawing the ears as well even if they're just place-holders cause they'll help keep the head shap from warping with each succesive frame
hold the looking at camera frame for longer before transitioning into the forward leaning motion also make the head a bit farther back in that frame or push it slightly forward in the final pose cuz if you're leaning forward you bend forward slightly rather than rotation forward while being stuck in the same location
also do the eyes completely open first and add the blink after you've smoothened the movement
i get the vibe you're going for but i think you over-stepped in that bit
as is anime eyes are already notoriously difficult to place properly since their orientation depends on the camera angle rather than some defined points in space

you have long way to grow young grass-hopper

>>6474417
You don't need to draw from a distance. It's always best to double check your whole canvas from time to time, or even better, to have a separate canvas always zoomed out, to make the process faster, but you don't have to always draw like that.
For me personally, rotating the canvas is essential in order to be able to make a nice line-art. I took this habit from paper to digital.

>>6474572
>Everyone including me draws this way. I zoom out and zoom in constantly. That's why I don't record my process. It will give people motion sickness seeing it in 4x speed.
You can create a separate static image if you want to record your process without all the zoom in/out and rotation going on.
This is how I do it:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iIi9WuR8b08
I separately also make shorter versions with just the static part.
https://twitter.com/BBCChanArt/status/1581691502677307392

For this you need at least an additional monitor, besides your tablet or main working monitor, but I guess that's kind of a usual thing nowadays.

>>6474228
I’ve gone through several phases of ‘fun pen’

many years ago I liked the 005 micron because it was so fine, and felt sexy to use. But it is completely impractical to sketch with because the nib wears down so fast.

Then i upgraded my paper from cheap copy paper to heavy smooth card stock. I was super into the 01 micron, until I discovered the plastic nib PN micron. The PN is super robust, and you can get some line weights with it. It draws fast and is my favorite sketching pen.

I used the PN until a buddy got me into using a 2mm lead holder with HB lead. Now for quick sketches I use the lead holder and went back to cheap copy paper. The toothy paper feels really good with the pencil.

Recently, I went back to the 005 on the smooth copy paper for some studies (pic rel). The 005 felt just as good as I had remembered, but you really need to be purposeful and you can’t just dick around and make scribbles or the nib turns to a nub.

Here is the list of pens I thought I would like, but find infuriating
>pocket brush pen
Fuck this thing. It’s too slow, the line weight is nice, but the ink is so thin and weak, I’d rather use a dip pen. I also hate the wavy hand tremors that show up when i draw with it. Definitely not for sketching

>dip pen
The worst pen. The learning curve is just way too high. I spent 2 yrs trying to ink with it. It’s even slower than the brush pen because you have to clean the tip and dip every 2 minutes. Then wait for the ink to dry so you don’t smear it. Probably the most unfun pen I’ve ever used. I never have a good time inking with it. The ink is either too thick or too thin or the nib is worn, the ink splatters, and my desk is covered in soggy ink soaked tissues like I just jerked off a swarm of squid.

I am using the gold zebra G nibs and talen’s india ink.

Getting the ink viscosity correct was insanely difficult. My nibs would also pool the ink on them so they wouldnt draw and it would just whiff blank lines on the paper. The only way to get around it was to clean the nib before each dip. I end up throwing more ink in the trash than on paper. Now i have this ink preparation ritual where i leave the ink in an open shot glass for 4 days waiting for it to achieve the right viscosity, and I check on it every day to see if its the right thickness.

posts.com:
Disney animator Glen Keane claims to have aphantasia. Do you think he, and other artists like him, have true aphantasia? I can certainly imagine that purely observational artists could draw well with aphantasia (in fact I could even see the lack of distraction from mental images to be helpful in this pursuit), but I don't quite get how an artist with true aphantasia could even begin a drawing from imagination. I saw him say that he starts with scribbles and refines from there, but starting with a rough gesture and refining is common practice even for artists who can see images in their mind, and I'd think a true lack of mental imaging would prohibit the placement of even a comprehensible gestural sketch from imagination.

tl;dr Do creative artists with aphantasia truly exist, or are they just full of shit/don't actually have thoughts devoid of imagery?

Hello, I hope I am not being obnoxious talking about my girlfriend again. But she has true Aphantasia (Cannot see any kind of visual memories in her mind at all).
However, she began drawing around 3 weeks ago and I am training her using a similar path to what Krenz proposes.
So far, I am seeing her progress faster than i did (I stand in stark contrast, as I am I can visualize very well).
Things I've noticed she seems naturally better at.
1.Organizing her process, from the steps on going from sketch to coloring to layer organization
2. She seems to have a better hand to eye coordination, has a lot of patience and works well.
3. Takes a lot more care in detailing, fishing, making something presentable
4. She is able to notice details in things that often go over me, as I am often lost in thought, that comes both for observation and general media consumption

I am curious to see her progress, and I'll likely post more about how effective the training is for anyone else with Aphantasia or who might simply be curious.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6475582
Most of us are just executing a procedure here and there trying to bend it toward "what looks good" with trial and error. Sometimes we have a strong idea and try to bend it toward that, but that makes the process harder.

I don't have aphantasia, but I don't have strong visualization abilities, and making visualizations isn't part of my or most other artists process.

I think you have some idealized notion that artists "see something in their mind" and mentally project it onto a page and trace. I'd be surprised if even one human artist on the whole planet does that.

There are artist that *do* have visualization as part of their process, like the late Kim Jung Gi, but another part of the process was building a library of processes by doing drawings from reference of lots of different things.

Draftsman, animators and painters from imagination don't have psychic powers. They just work harder than you and know more than you.

>>6473866
Never saw that drawing, but the torso looked blobby to me, and the belly looked rather concave because of the values you used. Also the hips seemed a bit iffy to me. Pic has the value shapes you used in red and blue is the implied form. The belly definition was just my personal preference. You can blur the abs and it wouldn't really matter. About the light, here's a tip, when you compare the rgb sliders of an unlit area and a lit one, and one of the sliders moves in the opposite direction of the rest, there's something strange going on. The exception is when the lit area is the shadow area of another light or when you're straight up changing hues. This is not a hard rule, but something to think about.

>i mean when you couldn't download it and you knew that
I felt stupid after I spent so much time putting together that imagine and re-read your request. You can get a script to do it with Tampermonkey, too; the disadvantage of these methods is that you're still up against a limit of how many pictures you're allowed to access in a given period of time. This limit regenerates pretty quickly, but not *that* fast. Like I said in >>6462087, there are books and collections on there worth many thousands of Gallery Points, and you'd hit your limit pretty quickly downloading those via script - anyone would.

On the plus side, it still doesn't cost any money to use a script ... so there is that.

as somone who just started learning the figure using both proko and vilppu simultaneously, it's astounding how different proko's approach to gesture is than vilppus.

desu tho, proko's gesture is much easier for a beg to learn. I still really struggle to do gesture in the same manner as vilppu and this is my third week grinding it.

posts.com:
The general thread for Manga / manga-styled comic-making, manga-style illustration and related comic work.

Support each other and talk about your work or the work of others that excites you. Inking, character design, paneling / layout, writing, planning, and other discussions are all welcome.
Post resources, questions, in-progress pages, breakdowns of other works, etc. If a work is not yours, credit the maker (unless it's fucking obvious like a full page of One Piece or something).
Thanks to everyone for making /mmg/ a level-headed and helpful place. Remember, drawing and making comics and manga are difficult endeavors, and we're all in this struggle together.

Previous thread: >>6430778

Some resources:
/asg/, our stylistic sister-thread series for those focused more on illustration >>>/ic/asg

Books:
Understanding Comics
Making Comics
Manga in Theory and Practice: The Craft of Creating Manga
https://mega.nz/folder/Dd4hnZTC#EjMIcTDPLbWXkAJLPHx2Kg
Story: Substance, Structure, Style and the Principles of Screenwriting
https://archive.org/details/RobertMcKeeStorypdf/
Even a Monkey Can Draw Manga
https://kupdf.net/download/even-a-monkey-can-draw-manga_58b9ca16e12e89233badd376_pdf
The Shonen Jump Guide to Making Manga
https://mega.nz/file/i81imLpI#GcheJ9Jjk3lw1RE9nQWgL4RG4wEBNOcRmgA-iaU6Wpg

Videos:
"Manga Senpai/Tokyo Name Tank", "SMAC! THE SILENT MANGA AUDITION COMMUNITY"
Habanero Scans: https://www.dailymotion.com/HabaneroScans/videos
Full MANBEN Series link: https://mega.nz/folder/9h1mUYSJ#8sJoO57nMP_JhjnujBXkpQ
https://www.naokiurasawa.com/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some western / indie publishers of Manga:

Saturday AM ( https://www.saturday-am.com/ )
> Digital indie magazine, seems to be on the up-and-up
> Open submissions for long-form series; also distributes series currently being published elsewhere.
> Regularly publishes one-shots, making it a good potential outlet for already-finished work.

Noir Caesar ( https://www.noircaesar.com/ )
> Focuses on black (specifically African-American) content, but seems willing to publish anyone good enough.
> Seemingly series-based only.
> No "magazine" style updates; series are updated on their own schedule.
> Seems less regular than Saturday AM, but also seems larger in terms of readership.

Oni Press ( https://onipress.com/ )
> Technically indie, but at this point large enough by comic standards to be mentioned in the same breath as other publishers.

Antarctic Press ( https://antarctic-press.myshopify.com/ )
> Longtime large-indie publisher of OEL / manga-esque books.
> Seemingly taking submissions at present if http://www.antarctic-press.com/html/submissions.php is anything to go on.

Yen Press ( https://yenpress.com/ )
> Started out as a small indie publisher of original / Korean material, and has grown reasonably popular since.
> As of 2016, it is also one of the western arms of the Kadokawa Corporation, with Kadokawa owning a 51% stake.
> Editorial inquiries can apparently be sent to yenpress@yenpress.com, however, they apparently are not open to new submissions at this time.

Viz Media / Viz Originals ( https://www.viz.com/originals )
> *The* western manga publisher.
> Currently in the exploratory stages of setting up an English label.
> Submissions are open and several books have been announced. However, progress on the label seems to be moving very slowly.
> Still might be worth a shot anyway.

Shrine Comics ( https://shrinecomics.com/ )
> Small indie manga publisher
> Seemingly attempting to make the transition to physical volumes
> Allows crossposting to other sites

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Other open comic publishers:

Dark Horse ( https://www.darkhorse.com )
>Dark Horse still welcomes your submissions, and all submissions will still be reviewed, just as they always have been.
>All unsolicited story/series proposals must have a full creative team on board. Writer-only proposals will not be reviewed.

Image comics ( https://imagecomics.com/ )
>Image Comics only publishes creator-owned material. They do not contract creators; they’re only interested in publishing original content for which you would retain all rights.
>Image Comics publishes creator-owned/creator-generated properties and THEY DON’T PAY PAGE RATES. Image takes a small flat fee off the books published, and it will be the responsibility of the creators to determine the division of the remaining pay between their creative team members.

Drawn and quarterly ( https://drawnandquarterly.com/ )
>Please email a low resolution PDF with at least 20 pages of comics and cover letter to submissions. Do not send dropbox links, scripts, or proposals. Please read our submissions FAQ.

Fantagraphics ( https://www.fantagraphics.com/ )
>submission page: https://www.fantagraphics.com/pages/faq

Top Shelf Productions ( https://www.topshelfcomix.com/ )
>Regarding submissions, we're easy. Just email us a download link of what you'd like us to review. NOTE: We cannot accept cover letters, plot synopses, or scripts unless they are accompanied by a minimum of 10-20 completed pages (i.e., fully inked and lettered comic book pages).

Additional publisher lists:
> https://jasonthibault.com/definitive-list-comic-publisher-submission-guidelines/
> https://writingtipsoasis.com/best-independent-comic-book-publishers/

And a new addition, not technically a publisher, but a new platform to host your manga:

Manga Plus Creators by Shueisha
https://medibang.com/mpc/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6449929
It's very good for making manga (page by page format) and webtoons (scrolling format).
Pretty much every professional that makes manga digitally uses it.
It has all the tools you need and the free assets store has a ton of stuff to make the creation process even easier like premade speech bubbles, manga backgrounds, effects brushes, 3d models and so on.
My only gripe with clipstudio is that the lettering system is so barebones that it hurts.
It gets the job done but it does feel very clunky doing your lettering in clipstudio.
I've only made comics in paint tool sai before and compared to that clipstudio is so much better.
Also there's a ton of tutorials on the creation process both official and by fans on youtube.
Just buy it on a sale.

They probably used something like blender to model and design these assets. Do the donut tutorial to get familiar with the interface and basic modelling + look into array modifiers and how to apply textures. That alone can help you get as far as how Shadows House got.

Most mangaka and artists probably buy 3d models off of websites like a Japanese equivalent of Daz3d and import them to CSP. CSP also readily supplies some 3d assets for free, and I believe there are some user-made content you can purchase too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6454002
I have only looked at the chapters so I can't comment on the writing.

I really like the composition and artstyle even though it's pretty simple and scratchy.
It seems to fit the atmosphere quite well.

You should really think about using proper speechbubbles or if you want to keep the uniqe speechbubbles you currently use then please use a better font.
Your current font makes it look like those old scanlations of manga.
Lettering is just as important as art and composition.
Blambot.com has a lot of free and good looking comic fonts for dialogue and effects. Blambot even lets you use these fonts commercially for prints and stuff if you're an indie artist.

I can also see you're structuring the panels like a manga or comic page.
You don't have to do this on webtoon because of the infinite scrolling webtoons have.
Take advantage of this feature and give your panels more breathing room and space between each other.
It feels very crammed and overwhelming as it currently is. Remember, there are no pages on webtoons. There's just one very long page pretty much.
Look at how popular webtoons are placing their panels.
You can do a lot of unique and fun paneling on webtoon that you couldn't do with a traditional page-to-page layout.

Also think about using more differently shaped panels.
It's fine as it is right now but it might become boring or samey seeing the same rectangle panels as you create more chapters.


Overall it looks good and promising. Godspeed anon!

>>6454002
I read the full thing. I though it was great, main thing I dislike is the dialogue. You should change the font, have speech bubbles, and also just go over everything to remove unnecessary lines, and edit forced lines. I'm also working on a comic, and it's definitely a challenge to make dialogue seem natural and not cringe-inducing. Try and act out the interaction in your head, and ask yourself if it would be like that in a real life interaction. Also keep in the mind that the character's personality plays a role in each interaction (If you haven't done this already, you should write down a document for yourself that includes your character's personality, motivations, fears, etc..) And another thing to keep in mind is that not everything has to be vocalized.

I found it weird how this main character knows English well when she was abandoned as a little kid, I think she should be more mute (Or maybe you could make her dialogue have a purposefully limited choice of words.) And like the other anon said, it should be explained how she built an entire house by herself, knows how to cook, and how she has money.

Overall I thought this was pretty cool and I'm looking forward to your revisions and more chapters.

Writing is just like drawing. Your first work will be complete garbage.
For some of the anons in this thread it might be their very first attempt at creating a comic.

Yup that's one of my problems alright, and I also feel like an idiot when I do the magic side flip. That pic says it all.
My particular design isn't completely unrealistic so it is by all means possible to convincingly draw it from all angles, but it's not only time consuming but just a touch beyond my skill set. I'm really studying the shape of skulls and the way locks of hair grow out of them, but then I also have to convert that to stylized shapes that suit my chosen style. Figure out what liberties I should take with shape placement at awkward angles so it doesn't look goofy. And then I'll have to be consistent with it every goddamn time. Bodies and clothing inconsistencies can be forgiven but when a characters head looks off, everyone can immediately tell something is off. I'm always amazed how mangaka keep their art so crisp for 10+ years at a time.

Indeed. And that's without even mentioning that these are the cream of the crop. Western comics have a bad habit of feeling incredibly immaturely created, not just in the sense of having very simple themes, but that their writers seem to have pretty surface level grasps on a lot of concepts. In fact, surface level is a good term for it. Now, I'm probably a lot more anti-anime and anti-manga than most people in this thread - I generally despise the modern state of them and think they've flanderized themselves into oblivion - but one thing I can't deny is that there are those stories that have that 'understanding' in them only a writer with deeper thoughts can have. That medium awareness that second order thinking that's usually reserved for non-comic mediums in western media.

This probably comes from the fact most comic writers don't own their properties and kind of get handed them offhand with significant limitations on what they must and must not do.

Also sometimes this shit happens.

>>6471769
I don't particularly care about gating an art form by whether or not you know the name of some half dozen artists involved in it, but I will say that comic book fans are more likely than almost any other consumer to specify they like a specific artist or writer, rather than liking a title. This is partially owed to the frequent reboots / Crisis events making a unified canon nonexistent, but more importantly, the long term serialization meaning that the character is heavily dependant on the writer and artist. Have a serious conversation with comic book fans about their favorite superhero or comic run and they'll probably go ''[This character], but only when written by Alan Moore''.

I do specify comic book FANS here, not the average consumer, because the average Marvel or DC consumer doesn't even read comic books, let alone have favorite runs. Making something appealing to the masses is an entirely different deal than making something good enough to have fans.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6476016
I'm not sure that there is any comprehensive resource on just "making manga", in the same way that there isn't one on making movies or making animations. There's too many elements to really cover, and most elements are creative, not technical, meaning there isn't a single "right" way to do it, merely wrong ways. The best way to learn is to make your own things and analyze manga you like, applying what you observe in your own stuff as immediately as you can. That's how the pros learnt, by copying the mangaka that they grew up on and branching off from that.

>>6465082
>What kind of benefits are you looking for?
>In this case, what do You want out of art?
I honestly don't know. I just get ideas that I think are worth realizing (but require very different skill sets to execute). I get super hyped for the final product, I finish it, and then reality sets in.
I'm asking /fag/ for advice because /fag/ at least seems to enjoy what they do.

I don't know if I do what I do out of boredom, delusions of grandeur or what. When I finish something, I get thoughts like "oh, well that was a waste of time and nobody cares about it, I should have spent this time doing something else". But then I get the next idea, and the cycle starts again.

I feel like I'm stuck in a catch-22 where I'll be disappointed in myself if I do nothing, but I'll always be disappointed by what I make.

It could be general negative thoughts from not having close friends or social status, but that's not easily fixed. It's difficult for me to build a circle around my hobbies because I jump ship too often to really "get good" at things (and being a /pol/cel doesn't help).

If I was smart, I would channel this energy into making some kind of soulless moneymaking machine, but alas. I can't learn to be content with vidya, weed and anime porn like normal people.

I think the TL;DR is that I keep chasing the dragon trying to make the next big thing, but I get easily discouraged and don't stick with things or chase trends.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6465582
It sounds like you're surrounding yourself with negative situations that'll never happen. Instead, why even worry about what ifs and just concern yourself about those issues Once you get to them (if they even ever come up). Overall, you're just over thinking and allowing your mind to wonder about possible negative outcomes that'll just never happen.
>I feel like I'm stuck in a catch-22 where I'll be disappointed in myself if I do nothing, but I'll always be disappointed by what I make.
I used to have this type of emotion. But in my case, I'd complete a drawing, be happy with it, and convince myself that I can never make anything as good ever again, and take me hours (sometimes days) to get the courage to draw up something again. I repeat this cycle upon each drawing, but now when I hear that voice I let it hang out with me. Instead of feeling doom, I'm just like "lmao you might be right" and just start on the next drawing soon after.
Overall, these emotions are gonna be hard to defeat. But instead of removing them, try to be friends with them. And you'll see why said emotions are making you think the way you are. Otherwise, you really have nothing to lose.

>>6472047
drawing furry stuff has leveled up my ability to draw figures so much because I want them to be in particular poses and have interesting designs. When just studying or producing other art I don't exercise the imagination muscle. Whereas furry stuff is like intense training of that muscle. And you quickly see when you're not doing well because people won't marvel at a well rendered furry image with no imaginative design/pose/whatever. It's really cool and interesting and I'm glad I got into it. You can see just in this thread how creative furries are because they're always exercising that muscle, and doing so in a fun way

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6472814
I'm >>6464532
and I've had some thoughts on the subject since I posted.

If one's parents are furries and this information is concealed from children, it would probably stem from concern regarding an audience.

>Child viewing parents
The earliest role models of competence in a child's life is the parents (and most impactful in most cases) and the goal of the parents (presuming care and responsability) is to guide the child's growth to become something functional to society, and also the audience/environment of schools.

Furry parents probably would withhold this because there's a lot of different places/people one may end up hanging out with within the fandom given that there's a huge output of porn and some very vocal weirdos that drown out the more normal ones.

Word getting out to a kid's friends might also make the "Anon's parents are weirdos" and lead to potential embarrassment from peers.

The parents also do not yet know what their child's likes/dislikes are and given that they will be housing the child for 18 or more years, everyone being cohesive is important, both nuclear family and external.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474152
hopefully someone will give you better pointers but from my limited understanding:
1. line width counts, use width to accent different areas, currently your whole drawing uses a total of 2 different thicknesses for outline + detail lines
2. you need to use more lines to define shapes, normally you'd do this with shading which you have done and is nice but that should be a *secondary* component, every region that has any roundness whatsoever and pops out from the perspective of the "camera" could have a line to accent it, like on the butts, on the face around the cheeks etc.
check a *lot* of cel-shaded art and do studies on simple objects to get a feel for it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474152
>>6474199
Cel-shading is just consolidating a range of values into a few shades. So studying values in general will give you the skills you need to reduce them down.
As with any skill, it's better to cultivate the proper foundation before you start trying to simplify things.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6428290
>It looks particularly bizarre to have the canvas and wood fins coming out of heavy iron/steel/whatever.
they are iron, on both of my designs, the lines are segments, but i can see why one could think they are made out of canvas
>also... why does it have regular ship screws?
because its also works as regular battleship if none of the anti gravitational fuel is available, the flight mode cannot be sustained forever too, because of the liquids properties (has to be kept at a certain temperature and mixture with gases to work/ overheating issues etc.)
>Show pipes or... something to differentiate from regular hull
i think its pretty distinctive from regular battlesip hulls, but i guess it could use more details, proruding pipes arent good for hydro/aerodynamics though., the fuel is highly explosive/hard to obtain aso it wouldnt be smart to have them visible, they are housed behind massive super thick armor plating behind the bublbs under the steering propeller arms, most of the magic is on the inside, like massive stabilising gyroscopes, special pipes and motors for the outside propeller gondolas.etc
also pic relatd are some earlier versions and a regular battleship

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6474936
It's just part of a small farewell present for a tank commander, commanding a mine flail called 'Keiler', which is German for male wild boar. He is also a hunter and comes from an area renowned for its woods and hills which were also painted by Casper David Friedrich a lot. I told the AI to create the painting in CDF's style for which the painting is much too bright and not detailed enough but I was still relatively satisfied with the result. It was definitely the best result of at least a dozen generations.

The canvas will probably end up hanging in his new office. Adding structure to it seemed like an easy way to fool most people who don't know anything about painting and only visit his office briefly into thinking this was actually painted by hand. I feel like I would be somewhat impressed to see something like this hanging in someone's office in my line of work.

People usually don't put too much effort or money into presents like these but I feel like it's more original than a group photo or a piece of shrapnel signed by the whole platoon. In the end it will have cost me around 40 euros and maybe 3 hours of work which seems reasonable.

Why don't you commission an actual fucking oil painting of this image, having the artist change it in any way you desire, maybe even to the point where it doesn't look like soulless twitter funko pop shit? ANY (male) art student in your area is going to be able to make something like this except better, for $3-400 easily, eagerly.
This image will always look digital, no matter what you do to it, even assuming a perfect print, which there won't be, because it's AI-generated sRGB. You also misunderstand how varnish works. Varnish settles. The reason paintings are bumpy is because of the paint, not the varnish. A brush will add "grain" to it, maybe, but it will still settle onto the even surface of the print in an even way, unless you flash cure it with UV or something, and even then, there won't be enough varnish. You can't just dump a centimeter thick layer on it, it will never cure.

posts.com:
Study light/shadow, do the usual meme with shading balls and shit, learn anatomy so you know which parts of the body are shaded when the light hits from a certain direction, paint skin hit by light color A, skin in shadow color B, use soft edge brush to blend the transition.
For shit like the dress and its folds as well as the back jewelry, same deal. Do a lot of cloth and material studies so you know which materials will have softer or rougher shadows, and how to light cloth folds.

>>6474841
>but that wasted time definitely won't make you worse at it.
It's a simple case of use it or lose it. Putting dozens of hours into a painting (as one does) is as helpful for your other fundamentals as laying in bed doing nothing at all. I'm not saying that rendering magically makes you bad, just that spending 12 hours on a painting is as good for your draftsmanship as not doing any art at all. It's nearly the same as if you spent your day playing video games or jacking off. People who got into art young don't have that problem because it's all second nature to them anyway, they can only go forward because those neural pathways that relate to art are incredibly strong.

This is very easy to understand if you have any skill you acquired as a child. For me it's the violin. I can play very very well and even if I go long periods without practicing I can pick up where I left off. I literally cannot forget how to play well, unless of course I get a stroke or something. Also the same with English (I'm ESL in a third world shithole), I always mogged everyone in all my English classes because I learned English as a kid, no matter how hard everyone else tried I would just be better without having to put in any effort. With art, however, I'm that kid who tries super hard to speak English and gets mogged by others who just had the opportunity to learn when their XP multiplier was at its highest.

I had this realization recently, there are things that I learned as a child that I just am good at. Then there's drawing which I got into at 21 (23 now) and its impossibly difficult to learn.

>>6474868
OK, go ask the ten million or so Americans/Canadian immigrants that moved there since they were 10 years old, that are not Mexican ghetto or 1920s Italian neighbourhood inhabitants or CCP spies, how well they can still speak their native languages as an adult. The answer might surprise you: They fucking can't. If you will forget your native language, the first thing ever put into your brain, that you are biologically hardwired to learn immediately and remember permanently as a strict necessity for your survival, then you will forget how to fucking draw as well. End of story. There is no such thing as childhood memory. You simply feel like things took longer to forget because you had lived a shorter amount of time, therefore things were "remembered" for a greater proportion of your lifetime, relatively.
The age where learning becomes more difficult starts in your 50s if you're unhealthy or have bad genetics(see: how old you look compared to your peers), and is a slow process that unfolds over your 60s and 70s until you die. There are no things you learned as a child that you are just as good at. There are no things a child can do better than an adult. There are things a high IQ person can do better than a low IQ person, and this applies to high IQ children vs low IQ adults, and that's it.

>>6472752
To summarize I think you're working with a poor reference of a woman who's had a lot of plastic surgery.
You won't get a drawing that looks right using her as reference.
The pose is also a little too symmetrical to translate into a good drawing.
You should also avoid those unconfident lines when doing lineart. Practice drawing clean lines in a single stroke.
Hope this helps.

Forgot to mention you should also study line weight.
Lines closer to the light source or further from the viewer should be thinner and vice versa.

yeah this is what I meant ( or at least tried to). where I see many people failing animating by mesh is:
1. only using linear interpolation, so lack of weight
2. using the same images/parts in for the whole
cycle, this limit the expressiveness and force of action.

If you are interested try doing this for the tits and pussy lips have 3 distinct images (idle, pushing max position and pulling min position) use the idle for the most part of the animation and in the finishing the movement of pull/push change the image (and possibly also the mesh and vertexes)

t. old opentoonz dev and helped a few people with this kind of animation

>>6475812
I made a webcomic about myself. Ive probably made about 150 strips in the past 2 years. Stop finding excuses to start and just put something on paper. It’s definitely one of those things you learn as you go and not something you can read up about. You can always restart it after figuring things out.

I’ve made 0 dollars. I have like 20 followers. I get 1-2 likes per comic. I made it for myself. Nobody really likes it except for me.

Biggest mistakes: wasting time uploading it on social media platforms and tagging it with useless hashtags. I got kicked off webtoons pretty fast, i had a twitter and an IG that take way too much effort to maintain. I was spending more time trying to publish it and get it out on different platforms than actually making the content. It was a futile effort to try to post it online. There is so much noise that you are drowned out in seconds after posting content. Like you are trying to whisper to your friend from across a death metal concert.

>>6396806
Soft shading/lighting with fewer steps. Gotta tweak the airbrush settings because default airbrush settings are often bad. If you use CSP, consider getting the “airy airbrush” tool. You can get similar results blocking in color on a higher layer then using a soft eraser, but a good airbrush will do that all on its own. Imo, it’s an essential tool for ani semi-realistic soft shading.

If you're looking for a place to post your cartooning then you've found the right general. This is /ic/s 1st and only merged hub where both Eastern and Western stylization can coexist peacefully, hence the double title.

posts.sub: Growing your platform as an artist
posts.com:
What do you do to grow your platform as an artist that wants a large audience?
Do you just post your flavor of the month fanart and let it speak for itself while praying to the algorithm gods?
Or do you create extra content to boost your engagement and reach?
I've been thinking of tapping into video platforms like TikTok but have yet to come up with interesting concepts that isn't just a drawing timelapse + music.
I hate the idea of becoming a content creator but what other choice do you have when simply posting your art doesn't bring any results?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Post good art, consistently. This is the hardest part for people. If your art isn't good - not "lowest common denominator", niche art is fine - and if you don't post enough, you fucking die.

For some platforms this means daily. For others it means between alternating days and 3 times a week.

Don't use it like a personal blog. If you shill paid stuff, make it "there but nonintrusive." Interact with people so you have a personality, and they get that parasocial dopamine hit but don't overdo it.

Don't watermark your stuff to all hell, and use a LEGIBLE, non-intrusive signature so people can find you - reverse image searches don't hit every site. No scribbles.

Post your art in appropriate places, preferably anonymously. Don't link or say anything, just share. If sauce is asked, provide it.
After you get enough traction, if you decide to open some kind of subscription service - leak it to kemono/ehentai/etc.

An artist's value is defined by how often his shit gets reposted. The more people who see your art, the more likely some will want to follow. The more who follow, the more who will want to interact, and the more who interact, the more who will be willing to pay you.
A lot of artists get a portion of this wrong and focus only on followers/watchers as a raw number, but if your art is shared without a lot of extra context then the people who go through the effort to find it are likely going to be "quality followers" rather than "inactive followers." The total follower count only matters in that a portion of that is going to be quality followers.

Note that SOME artists with good enough art (often in a broad enough niche) can compensate for failing in other areas. I have seen artists who shitpost and do the "posting screenshots and food photos" thing on their social media or are constantly blabbering in their journals on galleries, but the art is good enough to enough people that it compensates for it.
Still, if they didn't do that shit they'd be WAY bigger.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6472190
I should also stress that "interacting with people" means the people who are interacting with YOU. Limit it to things "about your art." Thank people if they like it (thank each person who leaves a comment until you're popular enough that it becomes too much.) If using twitter or posting in an art discord or something, don't post reaction images as that disrupts peoples' ability to find your art using ctrl+f "from:anonshithead in:pyw has:image" or the media tab.

If you DO want to use reaction images, draw them. Each time. Draw a new one. This limits how many you show, as well as forcing you to practice more. It also, again, does that dopamine hit of "OHMYGODMYFAVORITEARTISTDREWAREACTIONJUSTFORME" to the followers and encourages more interactions. Just make sure the people who you reply to with it are at least semi-random.

Yeah it feels pretty random. Some reels perfom shit and others perform very well.

I'd spread it out throughout the day. Maybe the 1st post in the morning and the 2nd in the evening.
Don't forget to use your story to promote your posts as well. Your followers won't always see your posts on their timeline because instagram is shit.

>Also any tips to improve my reels?
Showing the finished artwork for 1 second before the timelapse starts, gives the viewer enough of a dopamine hit to keep watching.
It's all about cattering to the adhd brain modern people have.
1 second is enough for the viewer to see but not process the finished artwork.
They become curious and want to keep watching.
Like jingling keys in front of a toddler.
The more impressive and suggestive your artwork, the greater the effect, I have found.

Hi!
I found pic related from a thread some months ago and it has actually been a great blessing for me.
I frequently got advice like
>just draw bro lol
clearly doesn't work. If you are shit at drawing and you draw more shit you aren't actually moving anywhere productive; Usually just stomping on a pile of the same shit making the same mistakes and missing the same key fundamentals over and over again.
>there are so many courses out there!
yes but which one?
>SOOO MANY
plz just tell me one :*(
>SOOOoooOOO MAnY
So here I am to tell you exactly what I did.

Following pic rel I started with CtrlPaint (its free, start with basics). I'm using Krita he's using photoshop. It took me 3 or 4 weeks before we even got to drawing an apple. Every 5 minute video lecture took me an hour of pausing every sentence to google how to do what he said on krita and follow along. Some lessons are missing the .psd download so I just screenshot his video and upload that to krita to follow along. Use your brain. I am 2k% more fluent in krita now thanks to this guy. There is no shortcut. You have to brute force your way through lots of "boring" to actually learn the program and its capabilities thoroughly. I'm hardly a L33T HAXOR now but I went from literally not knowing how to merge a layer or change the brush tag to making my own custom brushes and being basically fluent in the "photo-editing" aspects of the program. I even know where my resource folder is now!

Second, I decided to "sail" marc brunet's art academy. To do this you need to get qBittorent (make sure it's q when you google it). Then google "rutracker marc brunet", translate the page etc. use your brain figure it out (cubebrush). magnet link at the bottom of forum post.
Sail this course (its 36.8 gb). he says if you "attend class" and study for 3-4 hours a day you should finish his course in ~2 years. I just started but I am already so grateful.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474894
TL;DR independently trying to learn you waste 10 minutes (looking for books, doodling bullshit etc.) for every 1 minute of productive study. These guys (especially brunet) have thought extremely hard about how to get you from A to B in the quickest way. You should 80% study them and 20% study supplemental stuff that you personally like and want to focus on like anime or specific books like scott robertson - how to draw; which I am using to study vehicle and environment design.

I am in a lot of pain all the time I can personally maybe squeeze out like an hour or two of productive fucking anything per day. I have made more real progress in 1 month of CtrPaint + brunet than I have in the previous 5 or 6 months of grinding a few loomis heads every day which only demotivated me and made me depressed. Learning Krita so that I can comfortably draw while lying down in bed on my android has been a gamechanger also instead of trying to draw with pencils and pens and sketchbooks at my tiny fucking desk made for toddlers in my tiny rented bedroom. I understand the advice to start learning analog so you have less distractions but in my case I regret avoiding digital for so long.

Lastly I would say that if you are looking for a specific book you can look up zlibrary on reddit to find out how to access it on the dark web, or you could just google "book name/author name" + "pdf" and I just found like 90% of the books within minutes. Plus check the sticky since the loomis books for example are free (out of copyright?) just get them from there.

Efficiency is key and the advice people give on this board can be really bad. an advanced artist saying "just draw" to a beg is like saying "just sail" from your floating boat to a guy on the beach who has a massive hole in his raft.

I am noticeable progress at this point considering my disability. I think within a few weeks I will be brave enough to post something on the beg thread. for now I hope this helps someone.

-painguy

>>6474945
The assignments are probably the most valuable thing about the course. Take what I say with a grain of salt because I only got the course very recently and I'm still working through CtrlPaint so it may be a little while until I start really focusing on brunet but while I was flipping through the course material I just knew it was for me. Starting term 3 there is feedback videos, 4 videos of feedback he is giving to his students literally an hour long each! I obviously didn't pay for his course so no feedback direct from him or his group but this is the next best thing imo. For me personally when I judge that I am 70-80% of the way there to his example level then I would move on. You keep the material forever so you can always come back to it later if you find you need to go over it again.

He does say in his introductory video that each term should take 2-3 months at an average pace of 3-4 hours of classes and/or practice per day, so basing it on that it should be between 180 (2x30x3) and 360 (3x30x4) hours per term.

His course is extremely beefy. I am personally planning on taking it slow and being very thorough. At my current pace I would guess that starting from term 2 or 3 I will be spending 3 months at least on every term. I like to follow along with what the person is doing in the video on my drawing program and take very detailed notes so I am definitely not working through this as fast as I could be.

Although this is exactly the sort of thing that I wanted. Just put in the hours and get to where you want to be instead of spending hours wasting your time collecting holes in your knowledge from random shit on youtube. The tortoise vs. the hare. Slow and steady wins the race. I don't want to be a fucking beg forever. I would rather take my time and guarantee that I am making progress in the right direction. I don't expect this should be quick and easy but you probably also shouldn't be spending a year on 1 term imo.

>>6475157
It's very simple really. You may want to look up a tutorial on how to torrent in general. RuTracker dot org seems to be down right now but thats the site you want to go to. To translate from Russian to English you should use a browser like Chrome and then press the setting something like "translate this webpage". There will be a link at the bottom of the first forum post of whatever you wanted to download called a magnet. You have to click this special link and your browser will prompt you to open it with your installed torrenting software of choice (you should have qBittorent installed by now btw).

When qBittorent opens it will open the details of the torrent for you to review, including a preview of the files and folders you will be downloading which you can choose which ones to not download if you for example only wanted terms 1-3 instead of all 10. You can also set the destination of the download (I believe by default it is your downloads folder).

Once you click okay the download will start, and depending on many factors like the time of day, your internet connection, your geographic location, the ratio of seeders to leeches etc. it may take less or more time. It took me about 3 hours to download all 36.8 gb.

Also depending on your country or ISP you may want to torrent through a VPN connection (again google it if you are in Germany or something and need to do this).

All in all for saving 400 USD it's worth spending 40 minutes to learn how to torrent something. RuTracker is also a good site to know about generally. You can find lots of stuff there.

>>6472903
I’ll be honest op, it took me eightish years of ping-ponging back and forth between basic form drills, figure drawing, anatomy, shading, stylization, and basically every other drawing skill you have to learn before I reached competence.

What I’m trying to say is resources can be a good thing, a helpful thing, but realize that learning is not a straight shot from A to Z. It’s a gradual thing where you move from one topic to the next quite randomly and zip back and forth between them over time. You’ll slowly gain understanding and skill.

Remember to have fun and draw what you want to draw. If you wait around until you get good, you’ll be waiting a while. There’s no magic pill that I’m aware of. I remember filling out a lot of printer paper with shitty, stiff figure drawings. I also remember filling pages of boxes and drawing still life that looked wonky and doing more form drawing drills to improve that wonkiness until I was doing clean still life with good form.

Look up marks drawing tutorials on YouTube and see his basic drawing drills. They’re solid if you have trouble with form. For everything else, you kinda have to bounce around and study from various resources until you get it.

Early drawing is filled with a lot of fear, doubt and pain but eventually that melts away with competence, leading into confidence. Keep going anon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6413837
So Copic itself is a brand. I'm not sure if it's the OG alcohol based brush marker, but it's basically the standard. I would have recommended Prismacolor last year if you didn't want to splurge on Copics, but I think they're discontinuing the line since I've been seeing them on major clearance at every art store. With that being said, you could easily get a good deal. I personally prefer Copics over all of the alternate brands (Ohuhu is my least favorite and I think they give Instagram/YouTube artists free sets for the good reviews because they kinda suck in person). If you want new, you can buy them for cheapest on Blick. After Christmas, you'll see a lot of sets for sale on sites like Mercari and that's where I got mine for a really good deal. I like that Copics are refillable, and they get a lot cheaper to use when you're refilling them. Other good Copic alternate brands I like are Kuretake and Tombow (make sure not to accidentally get their water markers). Hope this helps.

posts.com:
>>6423644
read 'drawing lessons from the great masters' by robert beverly hale.
practice drawing cylinders and spheres until you can draw them in such a way that they're so good they look like an optical illusion. drawing cubes is to condition your mind for perspective so you should do that as well. by practicing these shapes, your paintings will take on their nature. as an example; if you drill proficiency of spheres into your artistic ability, you will be automatically better at drawing breasts.
the book i mentioned will teach you the fundamentals so that you are well-quipped to navigate the various aspects of art. it moreso teaches you how to think like an artist, rather than simply telling you what to think.
you can already do hands better than ai so at least you've got that going for you.

>>6460515
It's good that you took the time to finish it. Think of the first parts of the drawing step as being more important to the final work than anything else. Check all of your proportions to your reference, and when you aren't sure about something then you'll know what gaps in your knowledge you have to fill in. Be very careful not to simply copy what you see without thinking about it, as you'll grow very fast by being mindful of what you're doing. Keep finishing your painting like you've done here, and enjoy it. Keep sharing it with us.

With the grid. I just draw the important outlines. the pencil lines would be as detailed as this pic from google. Important contours such as the clavicle would also be marked with a line.
I take advantage of the very fast drying time of acrylic paint, I can just slather on colours without regard if it actually matches the reference image and I'll fix it on subsequent layers. This is why I prefer it to oil.

>David Finch learned how to draw by copying Bridgman's book pictures twice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6469065
It depends on your current artistic ability, the book, and your goals. There is no best way. The whole idea is figuring out how to change the way you make art for the better. That vision you have of what that means is an important part of this.

For studying figure drawing and "human anatomy," the entire goal is to flesh out your mental model of the human figure and to be able to draw upon that model (i.e. important details of the surface form and/or how muscles overlap or change from movement). You should probably copy (process drawings by copying them); doing so helps you flesh out your mental model. (Don't go overboard on your copies).

You then want to use that new detail in other contexts (drawing from imagination and drawing from reference). If you're at the level where you're making art on a frequent basis, then try to find ways to directly use it to inform your art. If you do not make use of what you learn in other contexts you are significantly less likely to remember it and use it. Your brain is designed to forget useless information and skills; if what you study from a book is not put to use it is just that, useless.

Forgetting is also common in the learning process and will vary depending on how much you already know. If you try to remember something you learned and forgot it, re-study it. If you try to remember something you learned and realized what you learned isn't in-depth or robust enough to be useful, you study it more. It is more important to become skilled in one thing to the point that it is actually useful rather than knowing not enough to be useful about a hundred things.

Don't let an art book consume you, this is the worst mistake to fall into. If all you're up to is reading it and copying from it, you're just pissing time and paper away. Remember that it is just a part of a reasonable artistic training regimen.

>>6461259

The only fun in life is trying hard to do something you can't quite accomplish. There is no real fun in accomplishing some definite fixed thing.

It is not easy. It is never easy. There is no magic about it. It is just as much a science as the science of a doctor. It has to be studied and worked at, and even then you never really learn it. No one has any magic way of doing It. No one has anything to start with except an over-mastering desire to do it, and the more you have the desire, the more you will work at it and the more you will learn. I am still working at it and learning, and that is all I care about. I don't care about the pictures I have painted. I may become fond of one and say "that's a good one but all I really care about is working at this thing, and it is still so far ahead of me that I shall never reach it, and have only just begun to know anything about it.

It's easier to think about things in terms of filters.
here's some:
you don't actually enjoy making art, or don't experience positive rewards for making it
you hate drawing
you only practice and never make art
you are addicted to dumb shit like videogames and don't draw consistently
you are neet and depressed
you have aphantasia and fall for the aphantasia ngmi meme and let it limit you
you don't take the advice other people give you
you have retards surrounding you that give you terrible advice
you don't apply the information/techniques you hear about to your work
you don't have the time to draw
you have the time to draw but don't
you are dumb as a rock
you never draw from imagination/memory

overcome your filters when possible.

The "language" of art is in things like subtle variation of line weight, color choices, perspective, lighting, composition, layering, hatching, shape design. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6462388
Blindly means without thinking. If someone does something cool, you draw it. No analysis, no thinking. If you mess something up, you fix it. you might spend 200 hours on the same image. By the end, you are simply able to do way more than when you began the image.

Photo studies are bad because they do not teach anything about artistic process. Many artists have a different workflow for photos than they do for personal work, or even master studies (copying other artwork). Photos should be referenced or analyzed. Copying them is often useless, unless the exact image is used for illustration purposes.

It can. Just not by people. The only teacher is nature. Go look at some nature (stuff) and draw it (stuff). That's how you learn to draw.

You can divide this up into steps, like,
1. Observe
2. Analyze
3. Make the observations and analysis part of your being.

and for that, we have three drawing methods

1. Contour drawing
2. Construction drawing
3. Gesture drawing

But ultimately, one learns to draw by drawing, and by comprehending nature, not by following advice, least of all mine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6456218
I had a similar issue and it might sound retarded but try going the exact opposite direction and take some time aside to do whatever you think would be the most miserable, unfun exercise. For me that was copying a Bargue plate. By the end of it you won't have burst into flames and even if it takes way longer than it should've or looks horrible it's not the end of the world and you'll have gotten something out of the experience.
After doing that I became progressively more ok with the idea of doing studies even though I used to be super averse to the very idea of drawing copies since you're going through all that trouble just to reproduce something that's already there. I understood the value theoretically but had no fucking patience to subject myself to it. Sitting down to study and analyze a picture can actually end up being really fun, specially if it's an artist you like. To me this was unthinkable because the only way I had fun before was making shit up and tossing the drawing as soon as I got bored.
Just pick one thing and stick with it, the more you do it the more used you'll get to it. For me, at least, the problem was that I was too used to drawing mindlessly as recreation so studying felt unnatural and scary. It's just a matter of getting used to something unfamiliar.
Again I know it's retardedly simple but I think it's the most reliable solution. Just be consistent with it and eventually the aversion will be gone. You'll always have plenty of time to draw your own stuff for fun, and it'll expand your options.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Either find what you like drawing, get out of a comfort zone, experiment by fucking with different media/styles, or find something else entirely. Even if you might be good at it, it may still not be a fit because you don't like it. For example I'm great at the physical and mental aspects of my work, but there's so much bureaucratic paperwork horseshit associated that it sucks all joy I might have from it.

Art as a profession is something one should take joy in otherwise while the skill may remain, the soul goes away. Art as something for yourself doesn't need to worry about it, and if you don't enjoy it, much as I hate the word, you're just being a poser for likes and (You)s.

Do what you love anon. Draw what you love, draw who you love

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6451437
Practice, simple as.
When I did go to an art school for a bit, I went in expecting to be amongst titans, but I still ended up being a big fish in a small pond, mostly because I've been drawing for longer than most have been alive there.
You just gotta do it over and over again, until eventually you can internalize steps and externally "skip" them, so instead of doing the rough skeleton, your able to go straight to rough details and all of that.
At one point I just went hard mode and exclusively used ball point pen to draw, so no pencil roughs to erase later, just try to make it look good in one go, results turned out to about pic related.
Just practice practice practice

Find the gesture, and exaggerate it. say their torso is bent to the right, and they are in sort of a ( shape, exaggerate that, push their hips more to the left, and the top torso to the right. posts.sub: Schizo take on social media feedback
posts.com:
So I just post stuff I've occasionally drawn on insta for the sake of it - who knows maybe it hits the right spot for someone else. I also follow a few people whose style and art I really like and sometimes express it through an appreciative comment, a share and sometimes join their art contests. Couple of them are big-ish i.e. 10k+ follows or something and they seemed to welcome this feedback to the point where they follow me back, "like" my work and sometimes we have a chat about the community and art or whatever. All cool. Nice.

The issue begins when I start getting praise comments/feedback from them. Of course feedback is nice, sure. Everyone likes getting that nice uplifting comment. But I really value genuine feedback.

Recently I've come to think the positive feedback/messages I get from those artists are just forced back scratching with no value. I may have no following and thus they probably try to support, but this support sounds fake to the point where it feels condescending.

Like, you don't give a shit about my art, why pretend? I don't draw things you care about. I'm no striving artist. I'm just an average joe pinup animeshit artist to pass my time.

I guess you want to get it off your chest that you've "now supported me back" since I went up your ass, but now it has an opposite effect. I don't believe anything they say anymore. It instead hurts because in the beginning I thought shit was genuine and I had actual artists liking my work. I gave up and disabled comments/shares. I'd rather get nothing over bs.

So did I hit a shit community corner where children are indoctrinated to hugbox or is this the norm I'm too stupid to understand?
