posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434940
I think 600 likes for 2k is a very good amount. Theres people with 10k who get less than that.
The usual tips are the same as always, drawing OCs from larger users, try nsfw, fotm, keep posting a lot and such. You are already improving as you keep drawing and posting new content, your followers notice that.

I think the luck factor is very important. Being in the right spot at the right time. How do RTs from big accounts work for you? Do they get lots of likes/follows? If thats so, aim for that.

Me personally cant grow by my own anymore as Im shadowbanned. I draw nsfw, not hardcore stuff though, just nudes. Everytime I post something new, my tweet gets hidden for at least 12 hours. It isnt showing in the search option, not by keywords, neither tags. I rely just on my own followers and luck. And even my own followers dont see my posts most of the time. I have 3k, but only getting 30 likes or so because of this. The moment another account RTs me, I can reach 3k likes. Thats really awful and discouraging.

I wish there were other places for promote yourself instead of depending 100% on that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6451767
I dont remember right now in previous versions, but you can press 'P' as a hotkey for the color picker

>>6451775
When Im first sketching a scene it looks kinda similar, its my style. But its been months since my last big draw. Think that I sculpt with my pen in ZBrush, so Im basically drawing in 3D, rotating 360º my figures and adjusting them on every angle, they need to look fine.

Creating 3D scenes instead of 2D, allows me to do many other things, like rotating over the scene, animating, scaling specific parts, changing the pose or working with cloth/fluid physics.

But the main reason for using them in interactive scenes inside Unreal is for example changing their clothes with particle effects, different hairstyles, or anything you can imagine inside a videogame.
Im still polishing my scenes but Im planning to make them downloadable with small minigames and such

>>6463841
I got in the industry by founding my own gaming company with colleagues and being employed there with an artist role. So not really your typical way of getting into the industry, but definitely one with the brightest future I would say. Would recommend over chasing jobs and clients your whole career.
But if you want to get into the industry, don't send the same portfolio to dozens of clients. Tailor it to their needs, show them that you want to do the "dirty" jobs as well. For example, if you want to do concept art, don't just put up flashy images of soldiers (they got enough people who want to do that) but rather lots of concepts for mundane objects that will fill their game world. But really, it depends on what kind of industry you want to get into

>Draw every day (or your preferred frequency)

>Spend at least 30 minutes on each submission

>Last Artist Standing (LAS): The original site, created by Lava (presumed dead, rest in peace). It has changed and ruined the lives of many lassies.

I long trascended fear and anxiety.

Tough the techniques that would fix your personalities permanently take too long to explain and apply, you can default to the Mind Trick, of which I should publish an article one of these days.

It's simple and it's something that everyone is familiar with, though nobody but me appears to have understood its nature.

Ever learned to ignore tickles? Stop shivering from cold? Stop sneezing?
It's all one single state of mind, and if you engage in it you're basically choking off some brain processes temporarily for so long as you maintain it.

Why am I mentioning this? Because another effect is that you cannot feel emotions in that state.

I tested many times, and I can guarantee it. If you also have the ability to trigger any emotion at will, you can also try and come to the same conclusion. They're mutually exclusive.
So whenever you start feeling panic attacks or other unnecessary feelings that lead to loss of control, you now know what to do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6475504
you can tell if an artist is working off of a sketch or not
if it's very clean, smooth and precise, it's made on top of a sketch, if it's "rough," "expressive" or "loose," it's freehand if the artist is experienced enough, most will do both
your average published, conventionally styled manga(and western comics too, really) is relatively finnicky and laborious to make, full of magic tricks and techniques that have more to do with crafts than arts, to the point where the transition to digital(which is what i'm assuming you're referring to when you say "traditional") adds only a little bit of extra "artificiality" to it, because it always has been, these aren't impressionist ear cutter paintings, they're products made to a standard

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

>>6466732
I don't think you really understand what the term "master study" means judging by the crap you've been spamming anon.

A "master study" implies you're studying from an artist you consider well-rounded and of a higher, established skill level. You do so in order to break down and understand the process behind the picture, akin to reverse-engineering it. It has nothing to do with them being born centuries ago or having their works on a museum's wall. Even studying someone else's study can be considered a master study.
The medium and style said artist is using only matters to you. If you believe Miyazaki's drawings possess something you want to extract and instill into your own art, then he is a master to you and studying his work counts as a master study. Same goes for some famous Twitter artist you look up to.

Forcing an anti-Japanese culture narrative or pretending to objectify what should be valued as masterful or not in the end just tells more about you people's petty complexes more than anything else.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6473037
He's showing the front plane of the pectorals. This plane is bounded laterally by a line from the clavicle (specifically, the point on the front at which the clavicle curves backward) to the bottom outer limit of the pectoral (just a little below/outside the nipple). From that bottom/outer point, an oblique line going toward the point of the shoulder is the base of another triangular plane, which is the side plane of the pectoral.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This has to be a bait thread, it's so fucking obtuse and I'm going to fall for it, right now.

OP posted a bunch of indie titles, and indie devs just need to be able to scribble their ideas on paper, list what they want, and have artists able to translate that into the greatest factor in what makes a game actually stand out visually: consistency, art direction, and most of all intuitive utility. A good game needs the player to be able to easily recognize interactables and landmarks in order to progress or complete a gameplay loop.

For a pro artist who's been hired for legit concept art for AAA titles that typically go for realism and fidelity in graphics, they need loomis, they need grind fundies, they need talent and skill. They need to put those things into practice for the intensive graphics the modelers are working with to translate into the game. they need to impress suits most of all for the money, who are just in it for the business, not because they even play video games. It's why you get trends like brown and bloom and filters that make everything look the same and people don't like it because nothing actually stands out. Feel pretty bad for them, proompters actually will take their jobs in their field when they put in a lot of work for the goal.

It's also why indie titles tend to have a longer shelf life: the more effort you spend on polygons, complex lighting and realism, the more a game ages as technology surpasses what was before possible in processing graphics. Art direction > Graphical fidelity.

>>6469258
OP , have you ever played a videogame?
In drawing , the visuals are the main and only component, you can't get away with bad visuals because visuals are the whole thing.
In videogames , the gameplay is the main component and other aspects serve it, artstyle (aka. graphics), audio (sounds/music) , etc.

In a videogame you can get away with a simple relatively meh artstyle provided it helps or at the very least does not hinder gameplay. Something like readability is usually more important than just looking nice but in an actual fight you cannot tell what the fuck is going on (unless the poor visibility is intentional, and the dev knows how to balance around it). This is because people are focues on the gameplay rather than the visuals.

For example in Among Us (Game where you have to find who is the murderer,who called "the impostor"):
-You can tell who is who if you just look at the color unless you are colorblind
(Among Us isnt very fast paced game so sillouettes being exactly the same is not a big problem and might help the game's "simplistic" look (not sure about this), colorblindness might be a problem , not sure how they tackle it (note that in the actual game you see the username above their heads , not color) )
-You can eazily differentiate them from the map

Minecraft (A 3 Dimensional block building game):

-You can tell what material is what (like telling water and lava apart)
-You can tell where a block begins and ends (if there are neighbouring blocks you might not be able to tell where it ends exactly (eg. grass blocks) ,but every block having a well defined border would look kinda ugly)
-You can tell mobs apart from eachother
-You can tell items apart from eachother (for the most part, if not , texture packs are your friend)
-Artstyle is stuff being made out of smaller blocks , realistic mobs and players living in a block world would look weird... as if they don't follow the unspoken rule of the game.

>Are they worth the exorbitant price tag?
Depends on what you're looking for. The Cintiq Pro 27 is the most natural feeling tablet I have ever used in some 20+ years, where working on it really removes that nagging feeling of having to double check your strokes before you make them thanks to how accurate marks are to your intent.
For the average person that can barely hold a pen to begin with and thinks that making 1248 wrong strokes but ctrl+z'ing after every one of them until they get the "right" stroke, no you probably won't be able to appreciate the difference.
But if you work with analogue mediums regularly because of how responsive they are and miss that when moving to digital systems, yes you very well might find the latest Wacom gear worth the price.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6469277
Tattooer here. I do not consider myself an artist. Actually, according to one of my mentors who has been in the industry for almost 30 years, tattoing started to tear off of its origins and traditions around the time some tattooers started calling themselves tattoo "artists".
I feel very sorry for those who have experienced the elders' gatekeeping. I have been incredibly blessed by not one but four ridiculous old monsters who have been tattooing for almost, and in one case, for a longer time than I have been alive, and they have been very generous and kind with their knowledge, experience and wisdom, so just so you know, people like that exist too. But to those who are just squeezed, juiced, used and thrown away, please don't get discouraged. Dickheads are found in every industry, and unfortunately not only those of sound mind do tattoos or get them. If you enjoy and respect tattooing, you are able to gain a foothold in it, and the more effort you put into it, the more you get out of it, always.
To everyone who wants to get into tattoing, I advise to seek out the roots of the craft, learn traditional artforms, be it western guache-illustrations, middle-eastern mural patterns or tibethan thangka painting, copy and master the traditional methods of tattoo designing, learn to value good foundations and technicality, and always, always be humble. If you manage to establish a decent portfolio, and do an as exhausting research on the history of the industry as you can, you will be miles ahead of the average apprentice (that I have met). My apprenticeship has started very shoddily as well, and I was almost completelt crushed by my first studio, but holding on was without a doubt worth it, and I would gladly undergo the 6 (sometimes 7) days of ridiculous 8-12 hours a day unpaid labor and myriads of favours once again to be where I am. Finishing a work you can be proud of is intoxicating.
I wish all you the best, please enjoy the journey as much as you can.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6473739

Not the same person but these are good questions.

Start by building a portfolio with drawings, paintings, different styles etc. go to shops get tattooed by different artists always helps (especially the place you'd want to apprentice). don't bother with fake skin or machines if you want to apprentice, just wait until you get the apprenticeship. Ask in person and bring a physical portfolio, tends to help with older people that might be up to mentor.

If you want to learn yourself there's a lot of info but sorting it out and making sure you get the right information can be difficult. I wouldn't recommend not having a mentor but it's absolutely doable. Make sure your sanitation practice is incredibly on point. Also you most likely will be worse for longer and pick up more than a few bad habits. Never buy the machines they sell on amazon.

>>6469409
I only bother with Patreon and Gumroad so

You have to skirt around Patreon's rules because the banks cucked them which means you're getting cucked too.
Also set up your patreon so that you're charging Patrons the moment they sign up a pledge. You'll end up getting a couple of people who will hop between different pledges so they can collect whatever you have and then leave so make that change in how you charge your Patrons first before anything else because Patreon for whatever reason doesn't have that set as the default
Cropping your images also helps with this but it also helps keep Patreon itself off your back. Because of Banks cucking them Patreon now has rules about what you can and cannot post on their site, so crop out the really bad stuff and only post those on your Discord instead

For Gumroad all I can say is that it's good passive income so long as you're actively advertising that you have one with stuff to sell on it. It doesn't have to be big things like long comics, some doodles and images with alts work too as well

Don't be discouraged when people inevitably leak your work. Sometimes you'll gain a few new followers who like it and will want to support you

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's my no bullshit method of having good drawing days
>Eat fish for its omega-3 content
Seriously just do it. There's a reason why asians particularly Korean and Japanese are high iq. Omega-3 helps supplement the brain.
>Draw ten 30-second gestures, five 1-minute gestures, and two to three 5-minute gestures.
15~20 mins of warm up sketches like this should be plenty to get your brain running. Think of it like starting up a machine.
>Surround yourself with high quality art that inspires you as much as you possibly can, or take a walk outside in a nice location
You are what you absorb. Most importantly, get off 4chan.

>>6471038
Here's a trick. Having a good drawing day? At the end of your session, start a few rough doodles that you're happy with, but leave them as-is with at most very minimal refining. When you're having a bad drawing day in the future, go back to those sketches so you can pick up where you left off, to help get you back in the "good drawing day" headspace that you were in when you started those sketches.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I needed an excuse to post my schizo theories

It's like anything else, the more you overdo it, the less the subsequent hits provide pleasure. Coupled with it being a learned ability, too little enjoyment derived in any given session will make it hard to continue and make one more prone to mistakes as the frustration builds. I see it as the brain logging learned information, and can only log so much so quickly, so excessive effort will diminish the rewards as the brain is like a SSD which can only read and write data at a set pace, and doing more is unlikely to net gain

A more reliable tactic is to do it regularly over time, counting the total length in terms of weeks and months rather than individual days, which are susceptible to all sorts of whimsy

Nice, colors look good. One thing I'll say though is that because the shapes aren't totally accurate, some of the magic of the light source is lost. E.G.: the match flame in the ref is sitting in his cupped hand, and the light coming through the fingers emphasizes this. Your flame is about the same distance from the cigarette, but the hand is further away, so it doesn't quite sell the illusion of the skin glowing in the same way - it looks sort of like there's a second, invisible flame further towards his palm. This is hugely nitpicking though, thanks for posting.

Shit happens and all you can do is move forward. I spent my entire teens + early adulthood symbol drawing with little to no actual guidance because I didn't know how/where to learn properly. But I'm doing studies *now* and feel better than ever whenever I see my small improvements.

That said fuck social media. Just post your work and move on (and you don't even really have to post your work anyways. >>6463664
Why does the top of the femur go all the way to the end his buttcheek? I could be wrong, but doesn't it end to the side of the thigh and not all the way back like you drew it?

The shoulders are shrugging upwards, making them more narrow, the torso is twisted a bit to the side, making it seem thinner, and the hips are sticking outwards, making them look fuller. The tail is wrapping around the legs, giving the buttocks a slight lift, also enhancing the shape. He is posing himself on purpose to LOOK more feminine, but there is nothing actually that off anatomy wise. Reminds me of the specific poses social media models use to trick the viewer into thinking they are curvier.
I think the body retains a decent balance, since the thigh is not thicker than his waist. He is definitely not meant to be a "draw a girl call it a boy" character.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I love /cbsg/.
I love how we have a place where we, the hope-pilled male-enjoyers, can all work hard and support each other so that one day we may achieve our artistic dreams no matter what condition we may arrive in. I love our vision to build each other up so that we may all climb the staircase of greatness together.

Many may not share our vision, many may want to destroy us and everything wonderful we have built here. Many who despise all that is good and beautiful. Many who are referred to as "nodraws". The nodraws may attack a dozen, a hundred, or maybe even a thousand threads, but they will never destroy what we have created here. Because for every flower trampled there will be more to take its place, for every harsh winter there will be a beautiful spring waiting to embrace us in its warmth, and for every forest burned there will be new growth ready to peer through the ashes and share with the world all its beauty.

In the pits of this war-torn landscape, there cannot be despair without hope, there cannot be darkness without light, there cannot be hatred without love, and there cannot be nodraw bottom-feeders without us drawchad gods! Without us, they are nothing. They try to steal from us our happiness and our joy because they have none of their own. Trying to steal from thread after thread without ever realizing that the banquet has been open to all since the very beginning.

Hold your heads up high, sisters. For the brighter we shine the more the nodraws attempt to dim our light. For the more we are unified the more they attempt to divide. For the more we strengthen our souls the more they attack us in desperation, hoping to shatter our hearts to look just like theirs. They push and shove with all their might, only for us to stand as still and tall as our collective resolve.

I love /cbsg/, because to me /cbsg/ is more than a thread: It's a feeling, an idea, a home.

You all have a beautiful Sunday, and happy drawing.

>>6472105
I was hired as a full-time remote concept artist, and a lot of job fliers online these days advertise 100% remote positions as a perk. Better than ping-pong and snack bars if you ask me. My company sold their office and opted for one of those WeWork-style offices where you can rent a space for a few hours for meetings that require in-person interactions and/or work there for "quiet/concentration" if you wanted to.

It's cheaper for companies to let their employees work from home if they can, and you literally have no excuse to turn up late unless you're sick. If you're an artist, they only really need you to deliver the goods within the deadline, with the final revisions included.

Life is good brehs.

>>6471718
Most artists don't get hired because there's not actually enough studios and a lot of smaller ones only exist for a single production or a couple years before collapsing. Either due to being a purpose-made subsidiary given to a specific lead by a larger corp, or from being led by incompetents.

A lot of people see this current state as the only reality, not thinking about anything which can give individuals the ability to grow their own studio WITHOUT VC/angel investor or daddy-corpo funding.
Kickstarter/Indiegogo and so on have been great for this. A lot of concept artists either started their own projects via those or were hired using crowdfunded money. Anything which reduces the barriers to entry for the quality ideas-guys to hire artists is good.
Quality ideas-guys are tested by the market, unfortunately, so without them having already made things, under the current paradigm it's a crapshoot as to whether you'll get a stable job from either a startup, crowdfunded, or brownnoser's first time leading a production.

If only there was something that promised to reduce costs for individuals so they could grow their media/game business into making bigger budget things after already proving their worth... Hmmm HMMM

I am still not understanding how this can be different from digital art then. Is not the machine doing the work for you? Have not the developers of the program you are using designed the software in a way where all you have to do is press knobs and tick boxes to get the brush you want to use and is this not a “machine” doing the work for you. If we were to get really specific, and even in this case this wouldn’t work, the only valid form of human vs machine would be if the human used a Command Line Interface and therefore controlled each and every aspect of the drawing. However, it is inefficient to use such a thing in order to create digital art so it begs the question how art created by a propriety program is any different from a machine creating derivatives of a piece of artwork. Would a few brush strokes on the result be enough to say that it was then created by said human? If we look at abstract art nowadays, you can see how this could work.

So as far as AI goes in the legal context, unless current laws are changed, it seems perfectly legal—albeit immoral—to do such a thing. Is that not correct?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6462462
It depends on the amount of control you have, not on the medium. With photoshop, you are using the machine as a tool while doing the bulk of the work yourself. It's just another form of a brush, essentially. With SD, the only thing you control is the prompt you type but you have little control over the actual output besides choosing one that's "good enough". That's why copyright claims over ai artwork keep getting denied on the basis of not having been made by a human and that's also why SD can produce "art" even if you type nothing.

The difference between digital art made with Clip studio paint and stable diffusion are that Clip is an instrument, whereas SD is the artist generating the entire image.
SD is more similar to command lines because you’re giving it autistically specific prompts instead of physically drawing anything.
If artists were just letting the PC do all the work the last 2 decades, why is it that only now the average person can make digital art?

Digital art is merely substituting the use of real physical objects. Having a setting that replicates the use of a physical brush is merely a convenience, because in both scenarios you'd still have to know how to use it.

AI art generators are more like classic patrons of the arts. The people who paid actual artists to do things. If you were inside making decisions on the design process as it was happening you could claim it's just an advanced tool. Like if I could tell it to generate a warrior and tweak the pose, drop and resize the sword in it's hand while adding prefabs of texture and design prefabs before proceeding, then I'm a fucking artist. Repeatedly giving prompts until you get a passable result is the same as having your brother beat the boss in a video game, it's not your fucking accomplishment.

posts.com:
Picrel is part of a ~700 page graphic novel that I have been working on for 9 years and still no idea how to promote it.

I've maintained a IG acct. that has never gone above ~180 followers and currently sits lower than that in spite of regular posting.

It seems like the only way to garner attention online since 2014 is to be political or outrageous, or to buy ads which I'm too poor to do.

I'm very proud of my work and got good feedback from a comic expo I did a few months ago, but getting people to pay attention to media which is not fear-based is exceedingly difficult.

Does anyone have any recommendations on how to promote yourself online? I already have an ass-load of material. Thanks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: do you have a twitter?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6475138
I tried Twitter and I don't think I knew how to use it properly because all I saw there was politics and porn and I got 0 followers after about a dozen posts over a week. I was also told it was a "dead platform" at that time.

Even though I dislike the atmosphere there, I'd appreciate any advice for using it to promote a comic.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>graphic novel
post it on one of the sites that host comics
tapas, webtoon etc

>to be political

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6475133
you seem to have an attitude that revolves around assuming people are all sucked into political stuff and can't pay mind to your work. let's bin that sentiment going forward and assume people DO want to see cool stuff and will gladly pay for your work, this will not have anything to do with social media metrics. that idea was propagated by those companies to try and trap you, it's also useless to you.

your coloring is super appealing, seems neat. have you looked into traditional publishing? look up comic publishers of various sizes and send some preview copies out, you never know who might bite. this might involve some editorial pushback and you'd sacrifice your creative freedom as an artist, but you shouldn't be holding any ideas sacred either way. there's also online web platforms for publishing comics such as webtoons just to name a big one

If that's slow going and you don't get any response, then distribute your content yourself through a paywall setup such as Gumroad or even Patreon. create an avenue for people to purchase your work if you haven't already. Once you have a direct form of monetization for said product, then it might be time to consider targeted ads. yes they would be expensive at first but they'd point people to a platform where you could see real monetary conversion and not just likes and follows.

hopefully throughout this you'll start to learn about what works and what doesn't. If you receive 0 interest from publishers or anyone at all, then you have to try something new and set that project aside. do something fresh, different and try new things until something sticks. treat it like blue collar work

I know it sucks seeing nice images with watermarks covering them, but with people just stealing images and trying to pass it as their own and AI generators being fed in artists images, maybe the easy (albeit shitty) solution is to just cover images with watermarks.

Not so intrusively that they fuck up the image, but enough that it's pretty much impossible to be stolen. And maybe some Photoshop/Gimp/Procreate plugin so that each one is kinda noisy/different so they can't easily be removed

Or is this just overkill?

>>6464068
Read how stable diffusion actually works. It basically trains the algorithm to denoise a generated noisy image over a number of iterations to produce an image (along with whatever NLP algorithm is used to interpret the initial prompt). Also it's unsupervised learning, meaning there is no real validation afterwards, it just returns after running.

What it means is that if the training images already have some proc generated watermark all over it, generated in a way that it couldn't easily be removed by existing watermark removal tools, than any generated images of that artist's artstyle (ie. generate xyz in the style of so and so) would try to include those watermarks as well and it would make it really obvious that it was AI generated because they'd likely be fucked up looking in ways a human could easily determine (ie. similar to how SD has no concept of how many fingers a hand has and constantly generates fucked up looking ones)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6464025
Retrained how?
Let me put it this way
1. Artist A posts a lot of public art, but all there art includes some watermark repeated, but altered in some semi random way based on a seed/key that only they have

2. This art is scraped and used as a training dataset for an art generation AI

3. Someone only enters the prompt "I want this image in artist A's style" and the AI creates an image

Now, because all of the artists images included that watermarking, the AI will naturally try to include something similar to it, but without knowing that initial seed/key the original artist will have an easy way of proving that this is a generated version, not authentic.

And even if someone altered the prompt to not include the watermark, and it manages to generates something that looks remotely convincing (although it's unclear if it could or how well it would look) given that all of the publicly available images include them, that's also a giveaway

Make sense

>>6471012

I make 95K a year doing storyboards in the US.

You have to stay within the confines of the script, there are times when you can make some changes but you have to pitch it to your superiors so it goes you > director > supervising director > showrunner/execs. If your change makes it all the way through that multiple times it probably will stay in through the final.

We do a lot of previs here in the US so shot composition, and fight choreography. but it depends. A lot of board artists in the US like to do almost key animation because there isn't a huge budget for retake animation.

I will say that you don't HAVE to be a super good draftsman to be a great board artist. But if you can combine good drawing skills with a rudimentary level of knowledge of animation and shot composition you will never be out of a job for more than months at a time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6471069
do you have a lot of free time outside of work to make comics / personal projects? How busy are you when you are actually in the office? (like, how reasonable are the deadlines?)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6471081

Yes and No.

Storyboarding is not a 40-hour-a-week job in the sense that. It requires such a command of so many different skills some of which have nothing to do with drawing; Time Management, Shot Comp, Animation, and Draftsmanship hell if your gonna make your storyboards you need to have editing know-how. So realistically you're gonna be working 50-70 hour weeks.

But there's a catch. A good one I might add. My schedule is roughly 10-11 weeks per episode. We turn things in and have to wait a week or two for notes and this process happens about 3 times after that 11-week deadline. So sometimes we are sitting on our hands or helping other teams on their episodes.

So if you make sure to hone your time management skills you can have a bunch of free time. But when we are working it's intense, but it's kind of made up for on the back end.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6471102
It's okay man, I lurk here from time to time but I only answer questions that I view as sincere. So don't worry about it.

I don't feel trapped at all, storyboarding exposes you to so much that when you're doing it you can't help but improve. I'm only a few years in but I know people that maintain a comic and board. The thing is that there are a lot of opportunities to move up (some people get in through nepotism, but not all), and with moving up comes a significant pay bump. I'm talking about being a Director (120-195K a year), but it also comes with more responsibilities and that means those 50+ hour weeks just went to 80+ hour weeks and on top of that YOU are responsible for how the animatic turns out, so more stress too.

I know people who just hit that 10-year mark, they are all mostly directors by then, and if they aren't they are just board artists that are paid well because they want to protect their time because they want to do what you wanna do. It's a balancing act, no one can tell you what to do. But the only way you'll know is if you commit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6473076

I started as a revisionist, I didn't finish school. I got more and more opportunities as time went on. Like I said above, there's no correct answer besides actual boarding. I know it's kind of a meme but everyone's path is different and you will never know until you commit to a path of action. I'll say this about portfolios, everyone says you should have 2-3 different pieces with action and drama, etc. But that's not necessarily true. I got hired off of a few action poses and one board. So In my experience, I would say focus on making boards and composition but also focus on life drawing and figure drawing, I mean actually sit down and work through the phases, lay in, contour, values, and finishing. A few hours a day thumbnailing for boards, and a few hours a day life drawing will take you insanely far. By the time you get around to finishing a board you will be better than you were. And on top of that if you always thumbnailing you will have a bunch of thumbs that you can draw upon to make into full boards in the future if you want to. it's a win-win. Also, learn Storyboard Pro as well as you can in school if you have access to it.

Game design IS an art form.

Back in the stone ages of computing,my roommate and I would deathmatch in a map that he created and filled with hidey holes and deathtraps, and I had to find him and lay ambushes of my own. I tried making a map and it turned out as a Temple to the OctaGod ,with a hole in the basement that dropped you out of the ceiling. I found Second Life and spent 5 years being amazed by the stuff that could be made. This was a dance club I made. New age music to slow dance to,scenic views to meditate in,and concealed beneath it was my store where I sold animated paintings and other stuff. Art is where you find it, and don't be constrained by your choice of mediums .

Latent space just embedding of a set of items within a manifold. Measure the items and assign a position so similar items (with similar features) are near each other. You can use Barnes-Hut transformation (i.e. dimensional reduction), to visualize it. Simple.

Latent space refers to a lower-dimensional representation of the input data, where each point in the space corresponds to a specific configuration or state of the system being modeled. It is called "latent" because it is not directly observed in the input data, but can be inferred from it, which means it isn't any form of compression retard, you'd have known that if you didn't read "Machine Learning for Transgenders"

>If you input a blonde human and suddenly when you want to extract your data you get a black haired human that also now suddenly has beard, that's not compression, that's transformation
That is because the act of typing a prompt is not supposed to get back the latent space representations of the input data but rather interpolations from the latent space. However, this does not mean that the input data is getting "lost" in the latent space and in fact all the interpolations you are getting out of SD are just various mixes of input data. That's why it's not wrong to call it a "collage tool", though I'd personally call it a merging tool

>>6470246
Ok i'm going to break this down. The clothing, is essentially a rough sketch, the anatomy, while the major forms are there, is simplistic, its correct in every way it needs to be for a cartoon character to look good. the hardest part of drawing a person, getting the hands right, is covered in effectively a sphere, because this is digital, the tedious work of all the action lines to go to a point is done for you with perspective.

This was made by a person who knows anatomy, knows how to use their tools to the fullest, and understands how to shade for illustration, and is likely also good enough with proportions to not need much of if any construction.

now an area where I believe he fucked up, the lines on the left side imply he is moving sharply to the right (image left and right) yet the hair is done in a way where it looks like he is moving left, a minor detail, but when im nitpicking that much to come up with a flaw, it shows the skill.

For me his work looks very surreal and dream-like for the same reasons as imprecise AI art is (in a good way): it tries to represent reality as best as it can but ends up failing (voluntarily for Beksiński, not for the AI).
Your brain can see and understand the whole picture but when you look closer it doesn’t really make sense in a realistic pont of view.
Details are merged together, unsymmetrical, there are limbs added or stuff that shouldn’t be there. Your dreams are the same, I believe that your brain takes imagery from your life, mixes it and it ends up being something confusing yet familiar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6464093
Basically
>choose image you want to copy
>draw a grid over it
>draw a proportionally identical (scaled up or down, or 1:1) grid on the paper or canvas you wish to copy the image to
>begin your copy
Basically having grid makes it easier for your eye/brain/hand to copy exactly what you see, since you're just copying several small images, each of which sits inside of a small square, without having to worry about the overall proportions of the subject or getting "lost" in what you're looking at.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6464093
>>6464126
if you understand better visually, here's a grid drawing i did

i'm not going to pretend like i know what i'm talking about but i think that the point is to help measure proportions on a smaller scale
instead of having to measure proportions using a very complex image with nearly no reference point, the grid makes it much easier to be able to get the proportions down with much more accuracy than if you had done the drawing freehand

by forcing yourself to focus on individual squares rather than an entire image, you basically limit the chances of failure which helps motivate you and at least make it seem like you're improving when you do start to get better
you can technically start off by just straight-up copying but if you're someone who is easily de-motivated, like myself, starting from the absolute basics will be helpful
the point would of course be to remove the grid altogether to be able to copy with accuracy without a grid

i believe other artists use it to be able to get an image down onto their paper with the most accuracy as possible which isn't exactly related to the reason that i am using it for

>>6463701
You're not supposed to draw primitives over the original image, you're supposed to draw it on the side. It takes longer to perfect, but that's how you learn. That way, you could still create the image (or an informed approximation of it) without needing it there. That's how you test your ability to communicate with images, rather than words.
Telling people that it's okay to trace will create bad habits that they'll fall back on, and therefore limit or slow down their potential.

Tracing really has no place in serious art, hence why only hacks profess it.
Even Norman Rockwell, who used projection image slides from photographs, expressed disgust at his reliance on it all, with his final works being much higher in quality as they were not constrained by it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hey everyone, I wanted to talk about something that's been on my mind lately: tracing in art. Some people argue that tracing is morally wrong because it's a form of plagiarism and doesn't allow the artist to truly learn and grow. When you trace, you're not really learning how to draw or paint - you're just copying someone else's work. Plus, it's not fair to the original artist whose work is being used without permission. Additionally, it takes away the unique style and voice of the artist.

Another argument against tracing is that it can lead to a lack of originality in the art world. If everyone is just tracing and not developing their own skills and ideas, it can make for a pretty boring and uninspired art scene.

I know some people argue that tracing is a great way to learn and improve, but I personally believe that the best way to learn is by experimenting and making mistakes. That's how you develop your own style and technique. And, it's not fair to use someone else's hard work as a crutch for your own.

Just my thoughts on the matter. What do you guys think? #tracing #art #plagiarism

posts.com:
Tracing requires skill to make it not look like tracing. The reason tracing is "bad" is because it breaks the social rules of artists.
Those social rules revolve around this fact: "Making art" is being an illusionist, and if you reveal too much you shatter the perception of the magic. But the issue is that artists are also captive in the illusion! Tutorials always leave bits out, they preserve some of that "magic."

Plenty of perma-/beg/ artists get pissed off when actual helpful advice is given to others because their own illusion is one where they "did everything they could" and just accept their position as being one of shit. Revealing that they could have been doing more makes them start to regret wasted time.

The same thing happens for less-shitty artists when you point out things like tracing are fine. They are idolizing the "idea" of being an artist. They strive for it. They hope for it. They look up to people. When you shatter that, break the idea of what they desired down into concrete, worldly processes - the magic vanishes. The meaning vanishes. They are left directionless and once again, their efforts feel wasted.
>If I could have saved time doing all that, and it was fine after all, then I would have been a dupe! I'd have been lied to! I'm no idiot, so you must be a fraud and wrong!

It's similar to when someone becomes successful while bypasses a culture, subculture or microculture of nepotism and brownnosing. Everyone within such a structured life gets immediately resentful, because they don't want their self-debasement to have been for nothing.
>We worked hard in the system, you can't go out here rendering that moot before our payoff! You want us all to lose out!

Many such cases!

>>6450621
Ok, its different.
I used to draw 2D years ago, I always loved art. I was also working with 3D stuff. But a couple of years ago I really wanted to try sculpting my own characters and trying that route.

3D as other person said adds that extra dimension and, unless you are not going to rotate a single degree your camera, everything can go wrong with just small movement. Do you know how in 2D drawing you are always mirroring the image just in case theres something wrong you didnt see because your mind got used to it?
Well, in 3D you keep rotating the model, zooming in, seeing how that face looks in that angle, from behind, profile, activating the perspective, adjusting the fov...

And thats only the sculpting thing. Then theres the UV, rig, weight painting, texturing (painting), knowledge of many programs (well I dont use Blender), retopo, baking textures, lighting, camera setup, animating and other extra things in Unreal like adding particles, C++ programming, cloth physics, environmental design, props, etc etc.

Here is my latest scene. You'll say:
>why so much work for something you can just draw?
First of all, I love 3D, pushing me over and over, making me proud of my work. The practical/useful part is I'm able to use these sculpts for many other things, like interactive clothes, changing their hairs, lighting/shadows in real time, making some minigames with them or anything you can imagine

well lets see here.

a good sculpting engine will handle several million polies without issue, so there is no reason to retop unless you want to animate or make a low poly version for a game

modeling is not hard, but it can be a bit paint by numbers and not fun, especially when its small shit for a background. (protip, if the shit is small enough to never be a focal point, draw it in as a 2d plane and be done with it, think plants and shit going up a building in the background, its never going to be close up enough to be seen so why do it right?)

texturing isn't hard, there are litteral banks of free texture data, if you are to retarded to know how to use them then 3d is beyond you

you don't need to rig or weight paint unless you animate, rigging is so retardedly simple I was able to do it as a kid in the 90's much less re doing it a few years ago because I wanted to try something.

weight painting is again, not hard.

lighting is literally done for you unless you are too retarded to understand the fundamentals of lighting a shot (protip, room lighting, positional lighting and bounce lighting are needed in every room unless you are going for a specific look. look into irl lighting to help you)

you only animate if you want to animate, and at this point 3d, and every step to get to animateing is easier and faster than doing the animation traditionally even when you think the 3d artist is a 100% beginner, and the 2d animator is a veteran who knows what they are doing the 3d will churn something out faster.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460952
If you're gona make a product with a vision in mind and with a level of mastery then yes it is hard. You would have to have a thorough understanding of anatomy to be able to sculpt a believable human character. Then when it comes down to texturing you'll have to work with skin tones, bumps and differences in skin etc.. the list goes on almost ad-infinitum. If you just want to create a basic human and you don't care about these subtle yet important details you'll end up with a generic monstrosity of a model like the vast majority of finished models out there.
It's not too hard to go through the process if you're a braindead cow but if you actually set high standards for yourself it is.
Look at the character sculpts made for dishonored 2 and compare them with models you'll find on any assetstore...

It's not that the tools themselves are hard to master necessarily but rather that the people who use rarely are able to discern due to lack of fundamental understanding and knowledge..

go with a style that lends itself well to real time or near real time rendering, this way you side step the autistic need to get everything 100% perfect, pick your shots so you never empathise anything that is shoddy, you want easier times animating hands or movement, get a setup that will read your movements or rotoscope from camera, both are relatively cheap.

>generic monstrosity of a model

on this specifically, it does not matter, as long as you aren't completely fucking retarded, you will have made the joints and moving parts on the model to work well with animation, again, retopo is a pain in the ass, not fucking hard. and good animation masks every shortcoming in a model which is a skillset that's nearly the same between 2d and 3d.

>but if you actually set high standards for yourself it is

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6472076
Sure
All the textures were done with Substance Painter, all handpainted (left image), mostly layers, brushes, shadows from baking the highpoly model and such. To be honest theres nothing procedural. I usually work on the 3d model and then adjust other details on the UV map (some normal/roughness maps)

The line art and shaders (right image) are done in Unreal 5. For the outlines there are many tutorials out there for a simple postprocessing material, mine is created with variable thickness depending on the light it receives, if it is overlapping other models, normal depths and many other features.
Everything is created using nodes and Ive been perfecting it for quite some time. The shaders work the same way, different instances for rimlight, amount of light, color, brightness, exposure . . .

The final image a screenshot from the viewport in Unreal. Shadows and light works like a videogame all in real time.

So my workflow is basically : ZBrush, Substance Painter, Maya, Unreal

>>6474358
Ok lets get a bit technical then
Last image is the detail lighting view inside Unreal, it helps me find out lightmap errors, strange lights or shadows, emissive lights and their possible issues.
The lineart is also an independent material and gets affected by this, for example my main materials are not fully flat, they have subsurface scattering. This makes the outline to react like on Kobeni's right shoulder, with a reddish tone.
Theres a LUT all over the scene too.

Yours looks fine imo. If it was my project I wouldnt make hard lights/shadows in the model, but thats just a design choice. I like to try new artstyles with every scene.
It could mean nothing, but try to give the background the same effect, fill it with colors or textures, that makes a lot.
Maybe your outlines are too strong underneath other meshes like hair (ears) or the shirt, try to change the opacity there

I think that the process of painting/drawing a pictore is so different from prompting that you have to doubt if the people labelling themselves as "ai artists" right now would ever have gone through the trouble of learning how to draw properly without ai. Sure, some of them were trying to learn it at some point but so were a lot of other people who never had the patience to actually become good at it and eventually ended up moving on to other things. Promting just happened to what this partucular group moved on to but I seriously doubt many of them would have become "proper" artists if not for ai. They'd more likely just be playing video games or shitposting on reddit instead.

In the end, comparing drawing to prompting is like comparing someone taking a photo of a landscape to someone making a painting of that same landscape. Sure, they might come up with results that look similar but the process in itself is so different that one person would most likely not enjoy what the other is doing and vice versa. Are there some people who like both painting and photography? Sure, just like some will combine the two into a single artwork but there are also plenty of people who only enjoy one of the two and there's nothing wrong with that. It's simply two different ways to produce an image.

Not saying this to defend ai by the way, I still think the way it was produced and marketed is shady as fuck and I'm all for regulations to stop these schizos from creating their AGI dystopia. But I also think saying "why would you prompt if you can just learn how to draw" is disingenuous in a way, since most of the current prompters likely would never have learned how to draw anyway, with or without the existence of ai

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6459289
It's actually doing the opposite. Most AI artists are just shit at using the AI, but it's genuinely leading us to more variation.
That's part of why the hysteria around all this started with Artstation-type "industry" artists. They spent their careers cultivating their styles to be corporate-friendly so they can hop from temporary job to temporary job brownnosing and trying to win based on groveling to art directors for a perma spot. They're literally all almost interchangeable though, by design. Companies want to be able to let people go and hire new ones without the brand image changing much. Think of how Wizards of the Coast's Magic The Gathering changed around when they started letting go all the trad painters in the mid 2000s, vs how little their "look" has really changed since around 2010.

I have seen people use AI to mishmash all kinds of crazy things and it really speaks volumes to how many niches are out there for artists to jump on. You want to draw coomer art in the old SNK style from the 90s? There's people who would LOVE that. You want to draw something like a combo of Saint Seiya and the chunkiness Jack Kirby? Someone out there is going to want you to draw their OC like that.

Most of the AI shit is generic but most peoples' tastes are generic because most people don't actually give a shit about art or interact with it outside of TV/Movies and SOMETIMES AAA games. More art exposure = more taste developed = more people wanting their specific custom ideas made by non-ai artists (and/or becoming artists themselves).

Yea I constantly see shit nobody was making before.
You show me people who were painting a combo of 1800s garden scenes with anime women.
You show me the artist who was making "[Thing] as an 80s [genre] movie" before.

The fact is nobody was doing this shit before and now the people with fucked up ideas can struggle with trying to describe it to a dumb text interpreter to get some semblence of a visual output, making something close enough to communicate "the idea of it" with even modest skill. And then maybe they'll take that to a non-AI artist as a reference!

Doing that process with a non-AI artist is immensely risky on both a cost and time level, for BOTH the artist and the other person. The artist may have to deal with numerous corrections, and the commissioner would have to first scour the internet for someone who CAN do such a thing and gather reference material that fits it, before having the interaction difficulty with an artist, the monetary cost, and having to pay for more corrections or going to another artist after for "this but better" if the experience and result was lackluster. Skipping that whole first step to the "this but better" part is huge for productivity for both commissioners AND artists.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6469580
That's pretty much the sentiment of most people who actually start to get closer to achieving "the dream" of being a published mangaka. It's so obtuse and difficult, the odds are stacked so hard against you that it legitimately starts to seem less and less ridiculous to just try and make your way in the busted ass western comic scene instead. The manga industry is incredibly competitive, it's a complete pipedream even for the natives, and you have all the additional handicaps that come with trying to learn a language and then do business in a foreign country (a notoriously bureaucracy-nightmare of a country at that) that treats foreigners as odd curiosities, and not only that but compete with the famously incredibly hard working natives to write stories that will capture THEIR local market, a market you almost certainly don't quite realize how different it is in terms of what appeals to and interests them in an industry that even within their work-yourself-to-death culture is considered to be one of the harsher vocations.
To get to the point, the closer to get the more you realize that you don't actually want to get it, and that you were probably better off where you were.

>>6469461
i studied japanese two years ago so maybe i can give some useful advice

depending on how good you want to be and the time you want it to take will determine how much time you want to put in
>about 6-8 hours a day to get good in 3-5 years
>about 4-6 hours a day to get good in over 5 years
>under 6 hours a day to get good in about 10 years
we're not talking being fluent, we're just talking about being good enough to have conversations without constantly stuttering and being able to understand most conversations that aren't too technical

the second year of studying made me realize the sheer amount of effort and work required in order to get good at japanese
i was pulling 6-8 hour workdays, grinding anki cards, and making sure i was good on my Kanji strokes and despite all of this, i still ended up with an elementary understanding of Japanese
sure, i can watch anime without subtitles but i miss about 70% of what is being said and can only understand simple phrases and conversations yet i felt like i studied so damn much

if you still think you want to pursue it, i can give more detailed advice on what traps to avoid and what study materials are actually useful but i'd say to study it because you enjoy it not because you see yourself in a year or so being good at it because it's honestly going to take years just like with drawing
basically imagine the skill of drawing and how long it takes to get good and that's similar to how japanese is as well but it's a damn fun language to learn if you're up for it so i'd say to continue studying it just for that aspect but don't expect to get "good" in a year or so because it's just not that type of language

yea, here's what i did that actually worked; just keep in mind that i learn differently from most people so this may not be exact

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RsrakMT1h2g&list=PLOcym2c7xnBwU12Flkm5RcLIEhvURQ8TB
>Watch all videos once without taking notes
>Rewatch a second time while taking notes
Personally, this was what gave me a foundational knowledge in Japanese to be able to study it from books effectively. Without Trombley-sama, I would've quit Japanese since I fell for a few traps that demotivated me previously. (Similar to drawing.)

https://a.co/d/3UCv3sy
>Literally the only book you need for Japanese grammar
>You can get more advanced but honestly that's up to you and not entirely necessary

https://apps.ankiweb.net/
https://ankiweb.net/shared/decks/japanese
>First is a link to download anki and second is a link of different japanese decks
>Here are some recommended decks
https://ankiweb.net/shared/info/2141233552
https://ankiweb.net/shared/info/1194221613
https://ankiweb.net/shared/info/266084933
>That last one is Kanji and will be very hard to learn so leave it for when you're ready
>You'll honestly know what level you're at and which ones you can study by the time you finished Japanese from Zero and gone through a bit of the Grammar book

You don't have to do it incrementally. If you get bored of Trombley (Japanese from Zero), you can try doing Grammar for a while or Kanji and then switching around to make it more exciting for you. Probably the best piece of advice I can give you though is to constantly do what it was that made you want to study it in the first place. The reason I stopped studying was because I stopped watching Anime and therefore lost my purpose to learn Japanese. It's a long journey so make sure you have a definite purpose for studying.
TRAPS TO AVOID:
>Reddit and their HORRIBLE advice
>Remembering the Kanji by Heisig
>Anything Abroad in Japan says to do
>Studying the Kanji in isolation
>Relying on Kana too much

Yea but I think it was mostly a waste of time. I'm very particular about how I study so it was natural for me to create my own decks that I thought were better than the ones online but in hindsight, I should've been "just studying" rather than doing that shit.

For Anki, I'd say go for both at the same time. It's going to be hard at first but your brain will eventually pick up on the patterns and you'll find yourself using it in sentences subconsciously. I only realize it because I would say certain phrases in the exact same tone and speed that the girl/guy says them in the Anki deck. Luckily, people have already done the hard work for you and you just need to find the good decks. For me, they were the Core 2000 decks on that shared Anki link I have there.

Also, I find that I cannot learn by studying one thing at a time. I tend to jump around a lot. This is important since you can get stuck on Anki decks for 6 months and get tired of Japanese so make sure to switch it up when you start to get tired.

I'm not trying to dissuade anyone from studying it but I was fucking obsessive with learning Japanese and I still didn't get to the level I wanted to reach which is why I always tell people to really consider it because this isn't something you're going to do in 1-2 years and be done with it, it's going to take a very long time.

>>6471078
i'm 6469610. I'm sorry to hear you got burned out on kanji. RTK sucks, kanji out of context sucks, bruteforce kanji sucks.

Kanji actually make a good deal of sense if you study kanji etymology. Kanji meanings relate to the components used to draw the character, sometimes it's only a small hint but sometimes it explains everything. The etymology also explain how the components gained their meaning; important because the components used to write a character underwent transformation and stylization.

Kanji having multiple meanings is in most cases a derived meaning from an earlier meaning. I didn't know this until I got the Outlier Kanji Dictionary (a kanji etymology dictionary).

For example, the kanji 解 originally means "to dismember an ox." The modern meanings derive from that to mean:
-> to dissolve, solve, unravel
-------> to untie, undo
-------> explanation, understanding

If you remember the logic and flow of the meanings it's not so bad.

>>6471073
I highly recommend you get the Outlier Kanji Dictionary.
You can probably learn kanji like I'm doing it now. Pick words that you understand well in spoken Japanese but don't know how to read. Look up the word in the Outlier dictionary, understand the kanji used with it, and make a card for the word containing the kanji in an anki deck. Start with learning simple 1-kanji verbs/nouns. Or learn the Grade 1 kanji first using this method because you are bound to have words to use for all of them.

When you are reading books, you can also do the same with words you want to remember the kanji for.

You will need to push at the beginning to understand how kanji work. And when you want to really commit a kanji to memory, you need to repeat the process I outlined above. But you are encoding the kanji way more strongly than most people as a result. Remembering becomes the easy part.

Since most words you end up studying are kanji compounds, you have two chances that at least one of the kanji make a lot of sense.

>new same price as huion, but cheaper to buy used (saw several 24" pros for $350 6 months ago)
Buy if you want a solid drawing experience, if you're buying used and want to save money, or if you absolutely need a dial on the side of your monitor. Otherwise just get huion.

Everything else (Gaomon, Ugee, whatever):
Don't bother, get one of the big 3.

recently got a samsung s7+ but no drawing apps on it yet to really say what its like compared to kamvas, but I will say this, touch if it could constantly palm reject is a nice feature, but palm rejection is hit and miss.

I also have a kamvas 13, but I just found that to be far FAR too small do draw on as a screen.

>>6467619
*Long answer:
I haven't followed any traditional artist timeline so I'll tell you a little bit of my journey and what I currently want to improve.
I've been pretty much drawing and doodling all my life since my dad was an artist so by the time I was very young I had already gone over "symbols" phase, I stopped drawing from 11-16 completely and at 16 I started to work online as a Fiverr artist in which I did mostly copying and painting.
At 20 I stopped working in Fiverr because I started to become unhappy and wanted to work on other things to make my mental health better so from 20-23 (current year) I've mostly not drawn or painted that much rather I've been focusing on running the family business and working out, however my goal has always been to come back and continue my journey as an artist.

Thanks to working in Fiverr daily, I can copy and paint extremely well, don't have a problem with values, I've started to imitate and acquire an artstyle from my favorite artist, however, my current goal is to improve and finish the perspective courses I left unfinished, study more to be able to draw from imagination and overall improve everything that has to do with linework as that's my weakest area.

**Short Answer:
>what level are you at right now?
Definitely Int, have no problems doing master studies or personal paintings for entertainment, my problem is I rely too much on reference and can't do much from imagination exclusively

> what do you draw like
I have a very specific artstyle in both linework and painting ( rendering) I'm trying to replicate and assimilate, I won't post a reference pic because I will probably be posting progress in other threads in the next few months and would prefer if I don't get some sort of schizo anti fan from this thread.

> what applications are you using?
I've been using Photoshop for the last 7+ years, won't switch to anything else really I've tried the other apps but I just like the flow from photoshop the most.

This is ironically a great book.

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

>>6471579
While you were practicing your Kanji stroke order you should have been practicing more figure drawing and painting as well. Painting wise you seem to try and go for shading without have any clear idea of what lighting you want or have any clear light direction.
>inb4 but muh diffuse overcast lighting

Even in natural diffuse lighting, since the day is overcast, all the shadows still have general direction of being opposite to the planes facing the sky (meaning all planes facing downward will become the darkest) The only real clear shadows seem to be on his pants, which have hard edges despite it being a diffuse lighting. The top planes and the sword has a bit of shadow and a bit of the arm it looks like, but its difficult to tell if that's actually a shadow on the arm or just part of a tattoo. The gold(?) on the sword and the arm looks like ugly cheese and not like metal at all, and the guy's muscles are pretty off wise, especially with the serratus and his lattissimus muscles on the right.
Those to muscles aren't inserting each other right and instead weirdly fuse into too long of parallel shapes. For reference, you can draw a diagonal line from the center of the collar bones (the pit of the neck) through the nipples and down the side of ribcage to to know where to stop and insert the serratus muscles.

Cute means neoteny, which is relatively smaller head to eyes proportion. Drawing a moth from behind means it's harder to see them big old eyes. Perspective may fuck you in making a cute moth, but focus on making the proportions right of head to eyes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6471967
Don't sweat the bullshit, man. Everyone wants to improve here no matter what their skill level. Getting and giving tips or suggestions is part of the process and someone voicing theirs about your work is just as much them reflecting on what they could learn from you (doing it your way or not as they see fit).

Since it is a heavily detailed composition, when I look at your piece my eyes naturally gravitate towards the sky because it has less contrast and less action. If you want to create art similar to classic WH40K stuff, you should check how they use colors and values because right now I don't think you are getting the viewer to look at the place you want them to look. Chaos marines are all similarly shaded as they are more in the foreground. Space marines being all the same doesn't make sense since they should be at different distances from the observer.

If you want to draw scenes like this, a big upgrade imo would be figuring out how the WH40K artists of old would make their images "flow" and guide the eye of the observer to specific points as interest. As right now I think making the sky the most comfortable place to look at is the biggest issue (sans any general "do Loomis" shit I could say).

>>6473164
Yeah in general you should default to painting skin very matte and smooth as 90 percent of people's skin you'll see IRL and in photoshoots aren't shiny with oil and usually have skin products on like makeup, etc. Unless you're going for a roided body builder or some fetish material with oily darker skin look its not going to look appealing or realistic. That sinix video explains the basic theory: for lighter skin, it has a lot of appeal when you have clear shadows and interesting design/hue shift in those, whereas darker skin you can apply highlights more extremely to pop the forms. This is why in model shoots you will only see oily skin on darker skin people, and for lighter skin people they apply a shit ton of smoothing and makeup to make the skin tone in the light more matte and soft.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6473497
Look at popular artists, go to gallery sites that may have their works archived (boorus, etc.), and just compare their newest shit to their earliest if they didn't delete it. If they have enough illustrations spanning many years, you'll find many whose earlier drawings look like deviantart permabeg sonic OC tier, turning into wonky but soulful anime, and slowly over several years it becomes what they can produce now.
There isn't a single magical trick no one's telling you that turns you from beg to pro, it's hundreds of drawings and studying the right things.

The reason you mostly see begs/pros is because begs are excited to get learning (most give up), and pros already made it and get to have fun. The valley of /mid/sery in between is something most artists weather by themselves. There's no motivation to post when you feel like you aren't improving much, because after the beg burst, your progress slows down and takes a while to notice improvement. That's why I tell you to compare anyone's art today to what they were doing 3-5 years ago, you'll see huge difference.

>>6474050
Did you ever try blind contour drawing, where you look at your hand or whatever and very slowly draw all of the edges and nothing else?
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blind_contour_drawing
Explanation's a bit sparse here but it gets you in the state of mind where you slow down and co-ordinate your hand and eye speed. If you do it as a warmup it might help you slow down and get absorbed in the drawing

posts.com:
Want input on my practicing idea.

I watch an episode of Attack on Titan (my favourite Anime for its art style - particularly how well it gets across large scale city and landscape). I've got an app that takes a screenshot at random and saves it. After the show, I take some time (quite a lot at the moment) and sketch WHATEVER the screenshot has grabbed. My logic here is that I want to be capable of variety and I want to avoid any unintentional bias in selecting images myself. Some will be hyper-detailed with dozens of buildings and characters. Others might be a much easier close-up of a face or a blurry piece of shit... once I've sketched out 200 pages worth I should have a much better idea of where I'm failing.

Quantity over quality is what I'm thinking.

If it matters, I'm a 34 year old absolute beginner with no talent for sketching whatsoever.

What I've found most difficult so far is scenes like the attached picture. Sometimes I can't quite make out what I'm seeing - can't make out the background at all (hoping this will help me to draw what I see - it shouldn't matter that I can't make it out). Also, as I'm just doing it in pencil I find it difficult to create any distinction between the darker parts of the cloak and the background, where they're the same darkness.

I've done 14 pages so far and I feel I'm getting something out of it.

A lot of what makes instruction work is your faith and enthusiasm in the instruction. This makes Loomis far above average because he is both competent and starts by teaching construction from imagination, which most beginners will find more fun than grinding studies all day.

Really, you need to stop looking for permission and get to work. All the most popular book recommendations are basically okay. The Russian Drawing Method is okay .Most Atelier's are okay. Construction and cartooning adjacent methods like Loomis are okay. All of them require a bunch of work.

>Is it there any plans to create laws?
Perhaps but their argument essentially boils down to SD having violated existing copyright laws in the process of training their algorithm because it stores a compressed version of a whole bunch of copyrighted images without permission and without any compensation to the copyright holders. And since I know some retard is gonna reply with "a-actually it does not store pixels checkmate lmao" to this post, PLEASE EXPLAIN YOUR DEFINITION OF THE LATENT SPACE THEN. Because strangely, no matter where you research you're gonna find definitions that describe it as "a form of data compression".

The problem is that since the latent space is not something that can be easily "visualized" by people, they think it's some sort of "machine brain" or magic (yes I actually saw a twitterfag call it "magic" today) when in reality, it's just a mathematical way of representing the training data in a very compressed form and all the "new" images created with SD are simply interpolations from the latent space.

>Can the tool itself be accused of copyright infringement?
No but the people who made the tool can.

>Even if the tool was, let's say, open source?
Something being open source does not mean that it's above the law

>>6473854
Yea basically, the patterns are clusters inside the latent space. The way these diffusion models work is they take some random noise, then try to "remove" that noise step by step in order to "reconstruct" an image and the resulting images will be interpolations from the latent space (which was constructed from the LAION dataset during the training process). Typing prompts basically points the algorithm to certain areas in the latent space (so if you type "cat" it will try to interpolate something from the "cat" cluster). Check out this article which explains latent space interpolation in more detail and shows how it differs from "regular" interpolation in the pixel space:
>https://hackernoon.com/latent-space-visualization-deep-learning-bits-2-bd09a46920df

>>6474826
>1
Calling it a collage tool when no one has found any evidence of exact replication of any of the training images. Not even exact replication has been established in cases of extreme overfitting (Bloodborne image, etc.).
>2.
What you faggots are misunderstanding about latent space is that, as pic related explains, the AI is not stiching together pieces of encoded training images, instead, it encodes the distribution of pixels in conjuction with CLIP language tokens such as the position of features such as eyes, faces, etc., to create a coherent image. The AI learns the average position of pixels relating to langauge tokens (“these many pictures of faces have the average pixels relating to face roughly in this range) and using random noise it can create basically infinite variations of the same prompt, since what it hallucinates from the set of pixels will be different each time the noise seed changes.
It would be physically impossible to fit the amount of images it was trained on (tens of billions of images), including the language model as well, in the 4gb forms the sd models were released in, even with the most advanced image compression tools on the planet.

>>6474917
>it's supposed to represent the SAME data
Not that anon but this is very false. If this were true, then the outputs from programs that implement diffusion would not be any different from the input.

Diffusion models are not just advanced compression algorithms. They are training a neural network to learn (yes learn in the sense that humans learn) what an image looks like.
The input pixel data is not used to create the image. It is more analogous to the processes of the human brain than to compression algorithms. If you want to say that the mathematical representation counts as a copyright violation then you will have to put forward an argument that makes humans exempt fom storing images as a representation because humans store every image they see as a biochemical representation in their brains.
>inb4 "but muh humans are different and special"
It is very likely that the functions of the human brain can be 1:1 mimicked using purely mathematical representations in the future. There is nothing special about the biochemical processes that govern the human brain which make it exempt from the laws of the universe.

Please learn how the tech works properly before you start making arguments against it.
Artists spewing arguments from emotion without any of the correct facts or use of logic is cancer.
