It was drawn in 1600x2000 then cropped down mainly with the brush size between 12, 16, 20, 24, and 32 depending on what the line thickness is. It's not a good brush for a single line drawing. Instead, you'll have to draw over your lines multiple times to get it to be thick. Keep it light and fast for the "skippy" thin lines. I highly suggest holding your pen either the way Nagabe holds his pen for solid lines and a looser grip for the skippy ones.

https://files.catbox.moe/1ndnwq.sut

>>6462015
I'm >>6461374, Lucid dreaming can be indeed hard to achieve and mantain, especially for people like us who don't exprience them naturally and effortlessly.

The basis is always dream journaling. You need to teach your brain that dreams are important, doing so will make them more vivid and detailed.
Then you need to set up a practice, make yourself think about lucid dreams all day, do MILD, WILD, and WBTB.
Perform reality checks, reminding yourself that the focus of them is awareness not the action.

Unfortunately, not practicing for a long time brings you back to the beginning. However, you don't lose your experiences and what you learned.

I too have let my LD skills go rusty, which can't be helped because I cycle between many hobbies.
It does piss me off that WILD is once again nearly impossible to perform, even though I had gotten decent at slipping aware straight into dreams, but I know I can get back to that level if I practice seriously.

I never tried supplements, so I don't really know their effectiveness. But if you don't practice the proper techniques, no amount of supplement is gonna do much.

I should weave lucid dreaming along some other mindfulness practice, but it's gonna be hard if my clients keep stressing me with shitty webdev jobs.
Stress destroys dream awareness, or awareness in general.

It's either praying the RNG or getting serious enough that you start getting serious results.
Personally, it's worth doing the latter at least once in life, so you get a chance to actually do some proper dreamwork. I've learned many things about the mind and myself.

If you want an all around practice to follow, you could try following the practice from "The Tibetan Yogas Of Dream And Sleep" book.
And I mean really following the practice to the letter. Bonus points if you understand why it would work and which techniques they interwove in that practice.

One of my two of my most successful runs was by following that practice.
The other was achieved by the usual techniques. dream journaling, RC, ADA, MILD, WILD and WBTB.
The difference from those successes and the halfassed attempts I do at getting back into it is the level of commitment.

I wish I had further tricks to reveal, or some easy way to cheat, but so far I got nothing.
I don't do supplements and I never tried those fancy LD inducing devices.

>>6463051
>how? what's the cheat code?
The cheat code is the following:
1. Draw something from ref.
2. Cover the ref and the drawing.
3. Draw it again from memory.
4. Uncover, compare drawings, note mistakes.
5. Repeat, Repeat with a different angle.

As your visual library and recall is strengthened, your ability to use them in creative ways improves. You can invent new things based on your understanding of a subject. Pick subjects you are very interested in.

>>6461332
Training imagination is training memory, not simply sitting trying to visualize shit.

A lot of people are mentally ill and have fucked up memories because of either that OR shitty medication OR both. For example: Depression is a decreased ability to recall good memories, so recall of bad memories takes over. Antidepressants "balance things out" by nuking the recall of bad memories to or below the good-memory frequency. So someone who is REALLY depressed or overmedicated will have horrendous recall.
Similarly, some forms of autism can impact recall due to interest and focus being 100% on or 100% off. That's how autistic children can rattle off everything about their special interest but take an extra long time to learn to tie their shoes, walk funny, etc. They simply are not paying attention to the latter but are the former. It's also why autists who are newbies (or perma/beg/)make very strange art: They are creative in only a limited range of areas because they only pay attention to a limited range of things.

In order to "train your visualization" you need to actively pay attention to things and TRY to combine them with others. Personally I have had a lot of issues with idea-generation, but that's mainly because of some tism causing compartmentalization. For a long time I often thought up ideas that I didn't want to draw! Not because I thought "my ideas suck" or anything, but I was getting ideas that others would find nice but that I had no care for. What was happening was that I was storing information in mental compartments, and just paying too much attention to things that went into compartments outside what I like to draw.
I am still struggling a bit, but it's better. I'm now able to filter odd and novel information THROUGH a "how can I make this fit the types of art I like to do?" filter before storage. It takes conscious effort but with time it's becoming an easier habit.

>>6469960
For consistency I would go all-in.

# Reality Checks
Nose pinch/Trying to fly//Thinking how you got there.
You must feel aware while doing them, otherwise it's useless. They're behaviors you'll carry in dream, and because you use them to trigger awareness they'll give you a shot at becoming lucid.
Of course, if you manage to be aware most of the day, that will by itself work.

# Awareness
All day awareness/Mindfulness: training awareness
Recognizing things as a dream: the dream yoga way, attaching the dreamlike element to everything you see in waking life, should work like a passive reality check

# Before sleeping
Meditate: several guys from dreamviews said it increased chances
Renew your determination: intent to lucid dream is important
Set the intent to stay still and re-enter dreams when you wake up: you can chain lucids this way, if you don't get tricked by false awakenings.
Set the intent to WBTB: or use an alarm.

# Waking up before going back to bed
Pick one of the many approaches
MILD: mantras for prospective memory
WILD: from awake into dream by keeping mind focused on visualizations

# Waking up
Record all you remember in your dream journal, if you don't remember try writing down sensations or how you slept.
If you remember at least three dreams vividly you're on target for consistency.
Be joyful if you managed to lucid dream.

# During the day
Awareness and Reality Checks
Try reading up about lucid dreaming.


You can do it by creating your own practice, or by following standard dream yoga practice (like from Tenzin' book). I had success with both approaches, because, if you analyze the book it's simply all the techniques boiled into a single practice.
And yeah, it takes time and effort unless you're natural, but if you do it proper it will work.

>>6460328
To understand the meaning of "Just Draw" one must first understand that the true definition of talent is the ability to learn how to do something well with little to no instruction.

Now that we have that definition out of the way, we can begin with why the "just draw" phenomenon exists and why some people are able to actually benefit from the "just draw" when others seem to find it to be a trap.

Once we understand the definition of talent, we can now see why the "just draw" phrase is thrown around as if it was the most enlightened advice ever given. It is not because it actually works for everyone but rather that it works for anyone who has an innate ability to draw--innate not meaning "born with" but rather a proclivity towards drawing that creates a natural ability to learn things.

In order for "just draw" to actually work, one must have talent in drawing. This talent will allow you to be able to draw for hours and learn from your work and mistakes without any instruction whatsoever--though instruction could never hurt. If one does not have talent in drawing, they must seek out help in order to improve or else they will stagnate as pointed out by this anon: >>6463757

Basically, if you don't have talent, learning to draw will much harder and even if you do end up attaining a certain level of skill, your art will never be as good as most of the worst works from artists that do have talent which is why you have to find a reason to actually pursue art. You have to have a purpose as to why you are pursuing it rather than just the blind ambition of being able to draw le cute animu grill.

The real question we need to ask here is that if you do not possess such talent, would you still continue to draw? That is the real question you need to ask yourself here. That will allow you to determine whether or not to continue or if you should just quit.

>The Process of Drawing
Here we go, I'll try to explain as best as I could.

The difference between being able to perform and being able to teach is based on the understanding on the process of that specific skill. Performers tend to not understand the process of being able to learn something and therefore are the worst teachers in that field. They tended to have received their skill by sheer mileage and have often taken decades to get to where they currently are. As they have not properly analyzed their approach and why they do certain things, they have an intuitive understanding of drawing which only helps them. Basically, performers cannot teach and can only perform. This is where you get the advice to "just draw" because performers tend to be the ones that actually take this advice seriously and tend to get good by sheer mileage rather than anything concrete that you can teach to anyone.

Teachers understand a skill at a much higher level than performers and while they may not be as good as the performers, they will often coach the performers regardless. Note how coaches in sports aren't usually better than the players on the team. (If they were, they'd be mentors not teachers or coaches.) A teacher must have a very high level of understanding of whatever skill they are pursuing as they have to properly explain each and every step--otherwise, they're wasting everyone's time.

For instance, if we were to bring this back to drawing, lets say a beginner creates a drawing. You notice that the drawing is shit but because you are a performer, you can't exactly explain why it is shit. posts.name: Anonymous

>>6472033
Chances are when someone is asking you how they can learn how to draw, especially on here where the entire board is literally dedicated to this one skill, that person has tried to draw and might've even tried to learn how to draw but because they are so new to drawing, they do not understand how to approach it.

Just Draw, to a beginner, implies that they just continue to draw their bad symbols over and over again until they eventually improve. It DOES NOT imply--as others have erroneously said--you objectively look at your drawings and analyze why they are bad. This is not something a beginner--especially those who started drawing late--will be able to do as they do not understand the process of drawing.

Because this is a board dedicated towards the critiquing of discussing of artwork, it was quite strange for me to discover that the only piece of advice that was thrown around was "just draw." When you pursue any other skill, you never hear anyone just say, "just play the piano" or "just sing" or "just code" etc. There are typically well defined fundamentals that even those who literally just started are going to be aware of such as playing the scales as a pianist or learning the absolute basics of coding--though coding is a bit arbitrary to be honest.

It wasn't until I started to draw a lot more that I realized that most people on here don't actually analyze what they are doing. They kind of treat it like a video game where they simply play and play and play the game until they maybe get good rather than sitting back and analyzing what strategies are the best, what their weak-spots are, and what is worth practicing. This isn't to say you focus too much on strategies, obviously there is a level of performance that must take place, but completely neglecting it for "just playing" or "just drawing" is quite ridiculous.

Yeah that's a good point.
A talentless true beginner artist will just draw symbols over and over again until they receive at least some instruction on the need to, and a bit of detail on how to, draw what they see. Of course "drawing what you see" seems obvious to those who have the innate talent to draw what they see (or have learned well enough to have it ingrained), but a lot of beginners do not understand this at all, and don't have the talent to discover it through pure trial and error. A skilled weightlifter will think using powerful muscles like your quads and glutes to drive through the majority of a deadlift is obvious, but a beginner with no instruction and no innate feel for body mechanics told to "just lift" will quite likely just limply fold forward and try to lift the weight using their lower back, probably finding the move uncomfortable or painful and generally failing miserably.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460328
since learning takes a bunch of time, the best advice they could give you is trust the years of hard work and eventually you'll see the results.

to get good results, it would make sense to analyze your piece after you've gained enough symbol making abilities and think (not emotionally, constructively)

> "OK, this I lack perspective skills"

this is quite simple to fix, perspective is very tactical, with enough grids you will see where you made a mistake, fix it, remember, draw enough to train your muscle memory and you'll draw buildings in perspective in no time,
if your hand is witty enough you can doodle something abstract in perspective. But to that you need to think with more IQ points,
there are some people breaking down every type of perspective while giving basic overalls on it, then apply into your art

>I don't know how to draw circular, soft shapes

from drawing a lot your hand should get smooth lines quite easily, practice drawing a circle, then lines curving around it, find other shapes from pictures and whatnot, draw a bunch of lines to understand the form, soon instead of blockiness you'll get smoothiness

hate shading? look at how it's done in real life, look at 2 values, thern add a rim light, then maybe really soft shapes with a lighter value, make sure to think how shapes reflect light,
find videos of light traveling across the room, going far and close to the object

you're an artist, and artist observes more than normal people, and if you wanna be a master, you gotta put in some studying into it as well

but never forget this, if you love drawing, you better draw your hands off and "just draw", and we promise you'll get gut

or take things slow, just remember to have fun in it too

More advice:

Stop being Afraid.

Mistakes,and bad execution will haunt you, but persevere in their despite. In my own case,what I present to the public is usually very different from the source material that I physically draw with ballpoint pens,and pencil for intentionally moulding into two dimensional sculpture that are my finished panels. But what I have "most" of are over 180 pages of a sprawling tale of Jeremey Prickles and a good 70 pages were literally storyboards of when I was able to Do It Properly, which means everything is made of separately drawn chunks pounded by Photoshop into story, So I drew it using the sketchbooks I was dragging into waiting rooms,and an epic story sprung from a random sketch of a demon head. It has both moments of revelation and whiplash pangs at your heart strings. I ordered a flatbed scanner so I can properly showcase my recent art,and the tale I am now telling,and the decision I have made. I am going to be 58 soon,and I am pondering how to proceed. I want to tell as many stories completely as I can, but I want to give the rendering enough work, to at least give a vague impression of what I was aiming for. To balance the art with the storytelling is a tightrope walk:in a page,I want to inch the story foward, at least from these current crop of characters (I had 3 storylines going at once,and all parties have joined up heading towards the end.). So I am just letting the story take me where it will. Yesterday I drew for the first time the daughter of two characters that were my Science fiction comics,a nearly extinct race of bipedal heavyworlder lizardfolk who fly with attached wingfolds under their arms,and they had retractable claws and 360o vision.

They met in a singles bar. Hey,6 was 14. Very 14. Well,there is their daughter stuck in fairy realms because she had the food there,and binds you to that realm. What the hell. Foward momentum!

Life's ups and downs can put you back in that spot (I call it "the tangle") but you can use total-breakdown moments to build a solid foundation. Actually, that shrooms trip was finally was caused me to cave and start seeing a therapist again after years of being staunchly anti-therapy. Forcing myself out of my comfort zone, finding new coping mechanisms, and figuring out *what* exactly in my life was making me unhappy helped a lot. It's good you're no longer able to ignore your problems. You will be okay anon. Life is really beautiful and you will realize this yourself one day, trust me!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Shroom thread?

I took ~3g a couple years back with the intention of figuring out why I struggled so much with art. I learned so much from that trip, but unfortunately, it all stopped sticking once the afterglow wore off. It did give me something to work from, though. Some examples:

>You need to put the strokes down, even if they're what you think are bad strokes. Get them out of your system, and you will better understand what works and what doesn't. This one blew my mind, especially since I would often take extended breaks from a drawing because I was scared of messing up with not placing a proper stroke.
>Everyone's art is worth appreciating. That doesn't mean everyone has to appreciate your art, but the right people will eventually find it when you put yourself out there. Consequently, you don't have to like someone else's art to appreciate them as an artist.
>Your older works are beautiful. Not necessarily because they're technically impressive, but because they're *your* works, and you've learned so much from doing them. You've come so far, even if you think you're stagnating.
>Everything will work out for you in time. Anxiety is an emotional state that often tricks you into thinking everything is doomed. Your ancestors were able to get through life, and their ancestors as well.

Pic related is what I drew during the trip. It looks like a bunch of nonsense, but it was the first time I genuinely enjoyed and appreciated drawing in years. Again, it's not like an overnight change where I immediately started liking art again, but it did show me that there was something to work toward. Since the trip, I've made, say, 60-70% of my way towards the trip euphoria, which I'm very proud of. Might sound low, but being on shrooms puts you in a very elevated state of mind, so I don't expect to be constantly euphoric about drawing.

Would I do it again? Probably not for a while, that stuff is intense and I've already gotten much further with therapy.

Currently doing an experiment on my gf (who just began drawing 3 weeks ago).
The training I am doing her do is basically trace for the first entire week. Then learn to copy for the next 2 with triangulation, grids and white space.
At around 100 hours of training, she is now able to draw what she traced and copied without needing to reference much.
So yeah, it definitely does work.

>>6471188
anon shoulder muscles aren't that big
the neck doesn't bend that far back unless you're an owl
even at that angle the distanc between the eyes is too small (they need to be atleast one eye-length apart)
try drawing the base of the nose as threee marbles placed ina triangle and then extending the pyramic and merging between the eyebrows
also if you look closely you'll be surprised just how close the eye-brows acually are to the eyes
the chine is never as sharp as you've drawn it
the arms connect to the torso slightly behind rather than exactlt the sides hence the torso looks wider from the front while arms look wider from the back
depending on the angle of the grip the pinky finger can actually appear way longer than the others (comparatively)
at the base of the torso right before the hips there is a slight indent that naturally occurs since the human back tends to have and inwards indenting if the person is particularly athletic
thehead isn't as big as you made it out to be with the puffy hair even the hairiest of people dont get that thick a puff (try drawing the peron bald first and adding hair later
this is all the nuggets of wisdom i can give you make good use of them

over all there are fragments of sovl but its not quite complete
please put in diligent effort so that we can see you blossom as an artist
ps the drawing might not be as impressive as you think it is don't go about bragging to your friends unless you wanna get cringe ptsd way down the line
well regards -anon
